PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small business;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under Common Law,
2. Deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. Could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should:
Completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights will do nothing to advance the rights of Australians, because it is dangerously ambiguous and will cause confusion within the legal system; it endangers our Federal System; and, it is to be administered in an authoritarian manner inconsistent with the present legal rights of Australians.

That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights Bill and all cognate Bills.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission on the future of the specific purpose programs operated by the Commission and seek leave to make a statement relating thereto.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I present a report by the Commonwealth Schools Commission on the future of the specific purpose programs operated by the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The report, `Quality and Equality', is a thorough and thoughtful contribution to debate about the future of the specific purpose programs and about our wider objectives in the field of education. I commend it to the serious consideration of all honourable senators.

The report is further evidence of the Government's determination to think anew and plan ahead in developing our education policies. In this report, in keeping with our Government's approach to education, the Commission has consulted widely, has re-examined traditional practices and the conventional wisdom, and has developed advice in relation to our Government's clear and practical objectives. This report builds on the report of the Quality of Education Review Committee. The two documents are, in many senses, complementary. Together they provide a conspectus of thinking about possible improvements in many education programs and plans to continue to achieve greater equality of outcomes and greater quality in our education systems.

This report has been eagerly awaited and has already attracted substantial comments from the States, from education authorities and from interested groups. We are digesting these responses as quickly as possible. The Government is well aware of the need to consider all the financial and other implications of the Commission's recommendations. We will be doing that, and doing it expeditiously and efficiently.

This Government is not afraid to formulate and implement systematic plans for our education programs. We are not afraid to publicise our plans, and to evaluate them as they go along. We are committed to ensure that progress is made towards the goals that we have set, that taxpayers' money is spent as productively as possible, and that Commonwealth effort is properly co-ordinated across the nation's education system.

The programs assessed in `Quality and Equality' affect not just children in our schools but all of us. They deal with the involvement of parents in helping and guiding what teachers do. They deal with special assistance for country areas. They deal with the use of computers and methods of training our work force for the economic challenges and technological changes we must confront. They deal with the place which teaching in community languages and cultures should be accorded in our educational systems. All these issues are integral to any appraisal of where we are going as a country and what we amount to as a nation.

For those reasons, I would welcome a wide debate in the community on the proposals made by the Commission, after which I promise a full response from the Government. The Schools Commission deserves our congratulations for having produced a document of this calibre. The report deserves to be taken seriously, discussed widely and evaluated thoroughly.

I also wish to note that the Government is proceeding simultaneously with completion of resource agreements with the States and the non-government school systems for expenditure of the significant additional grants which we are providing in 1986 under our general recurrent schools program. Those agreements complement the work done by the Commission's specific purpose programs. Our agreements ensure accountability for taxpayers' money. The agreements also guarantee that the extra funds provided will be spent on areas which we and the school systems concerned identify as of the highest priority. We are focusing our spending, we are developing procedures for accountability, we are making sure-in this as in every other field of education-that children from disadvantaged backgrounds of every kind are given improved opportunities for effective schooling. I move:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to make miscellaneous amendments to revise the Criminology Research Act 1971. This is the first occasion since 1971 on which a Bill has been introduced specifically for this purpose. The Criminology Research Act 1971 was enacted to give effect to a joint scheme between the Commonwealth and the States for the conduct of criminology research and the training of criminal justice personnel. These arrangements provided for the establishment of: The Australian Institute of Criminology funded by the Commonwealth to engage in research, training and related activities at a government level; the Criminology Research Council serviced by the Institute and consisting of representatives of the Commonwealth and each of the State governments, to make research grants from a Criminology Research Fund; the Criminology Research Fund as a fund consisting of contributions from the Commonwealth and the States, the Commonwealth providing one half of the fund and the States providing the remainder on a per capita basis; and a Board of Management of the Institute, consisting of three Commonwealth members and 3 persons appointed by the Council to represent the States.

The establishment of the Australian Institute of Criminology and the Criminology Research Council took into account a number of factors, including the incidence and cost of crime-the annual cost of administering the criminal justice system in Australia is currently estimated at more than $2 billion; the need for a systematic and co-ordinated approach to the organisation of criminology research; the need for a governmental institute to assist government departments and for a practical orientation to the conduct of research; and the desirability of avoiding the waste of resources involved in the duplication of effort among the Commonwealth and the States.

The Australian Institute of Criminology has, since its establishment, produced a wide range of publications, including publications on drug abuse, corporate crime, terrorism and Aboriginal criminality, subjects in which both the Commonwealth and States have a close interest, and publications on the prison system, alternatives to imprisonment, sentencing and policing, which provide Australia-wide perspectives. The Institute's data base relating to Australian criminological research is now included in AUSINET and is thus available to criminal justice departments and agencies throughout Australia. The training and seminar program of the Institute has also covered a wide range of subject matter concerned with the criminal justice system.

The Criminology Research Council has provided funds for more than 120 separate research projects focusing on virtually all aspects of crime and criminal justice in Australia. Research conducted by the Institute has had a national and comparative orientation which enables the Commonwealth and each State to measure its own achievements against that of other jurisdictions and to be alerted to successful initiatives that have been attempted elsewhere. In addition, the Institution has more recently undertaken primary research into such matters as the enforcement of laws relating to occupational health and safety, the development of alternative modes of handling criminal justice matters relating to Aboriginal offenders and the participation of young people in crime, particularly property offences.

In contrast to research conducted by the Institute, research funded by the Criminology Research Council has for the most part related to State or local problems, rather than problems having a national orientation and the research has been primarily evaluative of existing systems within State jurisdiction. The Institute and the Council have paid particular attention to the development of research likely to have practical value in the formulation of criminal justice policies. Research of the Institute and research sponsored by the Council has made a direct input into the development of criminal justice policy. For example, the Institute has undertaken a substantial amount of research for the Meetings of Ministers responsible for Prisons, Probation and Parole; research funded by the Council on gun laws has led to legislative changes in a number of States.

In July 1985, a Review Team was established to examine the functions of certain statutory authorities, including the Institute, falling within the responsibility of the portfolio of the Attorney-General. The Review Team has made some suggestions for the amendment to the Criminology Research Act, and the present Bill incorporates those suggestions.

I turn now to the contents of the present Bill. One of the main purposes of the Bill is to enable the Northern Territory to become a participant in the joint Commonwealth-State scheme established by the Act. The Northern Territory administration has indicated its agreement to the proposal.

The Bill introduces amendments to increase the size of the Criminology Research Council from 7 to 8, consequent upon the addition of the Northern Territory. A consequential increase is also made to the size of the Board of Management of the Institute from six to eight. This will allow four State members, instead of three to be appointed to the Board and four Commonwealth members which will include the Director of the Institute, and three members appointed by the Attorney-General. The Director is to become a member of the Board in line with current practice in similar Commonwealth legislation.

The Bill also introduces amendments to clarify the functions of the Institute by giving the Institute specific authority to collect information and statistics, without detracting from, and in the context of, the overall collecting and co-ordinating role of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In addition, specific authority is given to the Institute to provide information and advice to Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory criminal justice departments and agencies, and to collaborate with bodies in Australia and overseas. The Review Team that I have mentioned recommended that the Act should be amended to enable the Attorney-General to request the Institute to conduct a particular research or training project as one to which the Institute's Board of Management should give priority. The Bill includes a provision to give effect to this suggestion.

Miscellaneous amendments are made on financial and administrative matters to update provisions on those matters. The Bill makes specific provision for the Institute to enter into contracts. This will enable the Institute to enter into contracts with Commonwealth or State departments or agencies for the conduct by the Institute of criminological research, and for the expending of moneys by the Institute pursuant to those contracts. The Bill also contains an amendment to place beyond doubt the Institute's power to arrange for research to be carried out by others as well as to conduct research itself. In addition, the Bill will enable sitting fees to be paid to non-public service members of the Board of Management of the Institute.

Finally, a schedule is included in the Bill of minor amendments of a drafting nature which, among other things, remove instances of gender specific language and replace them with gender neutral language in line with current Government policy. The financial considerations arising from the proposed amendments are minimal. The cost to the Commonwealth will be about $800 per annum for remuneration of the non-public servant member of the Board of Management. The cost to the Northern Territory will be about $700 per annum, in respect of its contribution to the Criminology Research Fund, plus the cost of sending a representative to meetings four times a year. The Northern Territory could minimize the latter costs by appointing a local deputy to attend meetings where required. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Senator Macklin:
That regulation 2 of the Overseas Students Charge Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1985 No. 352 and made under the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The number of students who come from overseas to study in Australia is an indication of the high regard in which Australian education is held. At present there are about 20,000 overseas students in Australia. Although Australia welcomes overseas students, this country cannot be expected to bear the full cost of their education. As it is, some cost recovery occurs, but it must be remembered that the Australian taxpayer is paying a subsidy towards these students' education. Cost recovery takes place through the overseas students charge. This was introduced in 1980. Apart from 1981, there has been an annual increase to new and continuing students. These increases have been greater than changes to the Consumer price index and have generally been in the region of 15 per cent. For example, the bulk of undergraduate students were paying $1,500 in 1980 and 1981. This increased by 13 per cent in 1982, 9 per cent in 1983, and 16 per cent in 1984 and 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: An amendment to the Act was sought in March 1985 to allow the charge to increase in 1986 to 35 per cent of the average full cost of a tertiary place in Australia. The new charge for medical, dentistry and veterinary courses was to be $4,340. For all other courses the charge was to be $3,500. These charges also ended the discrimination between post-graduate and under- graduate students. Up until now post-graduates have paid more than undergraduates in the same faculty. The anticipated revenue in 1985-86 was $42.4m. The Australian Democrats sought to amend the Bill so that a student's charge would be pegged at the level relevant to the first year of study. Thus the bulk of students who in 1985 paid $2,500 would go on paying that amount throughout their time in Australia. Anticipated revenue in 1985-86 from this option was $34m; that is, a $8m loss. In 1986-87 the loss would be about $20m.

The Government therefore determined a compromise position and this was moved as a formal amendment on 20 November. The compromise was eventually accepted by the Senate. The compromise allowed for new students in 1986 a charge of $4,340 for medicine, veterinary science or dentistry, or $3,500 for all other courses. This is an increase of 40 per cent on 1985 charges for the majority of students. For continuing students, the charge was to increase by a maximum of 15 per cent on that levied for 1985. The amount would be $3,565 for medicine, veterinary science or dentistry-that was previously $3,100-or $2,875 for all other courses, which was previously $2,500. In future years, the cohort of students who commenced tertiary study in or before 1985 would continue to face a maximum 15 per cent charge increase per annum. No indication was given in the Bill of likely charges for those students who commenced study in or after 1986, but the Minister's speech indicated that in 1987 the charge would rise to 45 per cent of the average full cost of a tertiary place in Australia.

The charges agreed upon have subsequently been promulgated by a regulation and that is the regulation which Senator Macklin has moved to disallow. The effect of Senator Macklin's motion is to disallow proposed 1986 levels of the charge for both new and continuing students. All students would, therefore, pay the levels of charge which are provided for in the legislation prior to amendment. These are the 1985 levels which are: $3,350 for a post-graduate; $3,100 for undergraduate medicine, dentistry and veterinary science; and $2,500 for other undergraduates. It should be noted that a differential charge for post-graduate students, which was removed by the regulation, would be retained if Senator Macklin's motion were successful.

What are the reasons for the Government's rejection of Senator Macklin's disallowance motion? One reason is related to costs. Disallowance would result in a decrease of approximately $11m in estimated revenue from the overseas students charge in 1985-86. The Government, and thus the Australian taxpayers, subsidy would rise by a commensurate amount. As well, there would be certain administrative consequences. About 500 new students have already paid the charge at the 1986 levels. Continuing students, whose payments are due by 15 March, have also commenced payment and their numbers will increase quite rapidly during the next few weeks. Refunds will have to be calculated and made to those students, with associated increases in administrative work load, which the overseas student office can ill afford. Additionally, should a new level or charge for continuing students result-for example, in an increase of 8 per cent in lieu of the proposed 15 per cent-all students payments would require adjustment.

Procedures have been designed to enable follow up of non-payers immediately after 15 March to avoid the problems of late termination and possible deportation which arose last year. Confusion about liability is certain to arise, however, if charge levels change, jeopardising efficient operation of the new procedures. The Government holds that the regulations should stand and therefore rejects the motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support the motion of disallowance. This matter was substantially debated on 28 November last year when the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill was before the Senate. It had been rushed through the House of Representatives with inadequate and very brief debate, but in the Senate we had the ability to give a summary view of this important matter. Rather than repeat all of those points I can only say that the Opposition approach in this matter is to refer to what was said on 28 November last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Colston's summary just now was accurate except in one matter. While there were three initial positions-the Government's proposal for a 40 per cent increase in the charge for all students; the Australian Democrats opposition to any increase; and the Opposition's position of having a moderate increase, and at one stage figures were suggested for that increase-this led, as Senator Colston said, to a compromise position being put forward by the Government. That compromise was for a fixed 15 per cent increase for each year for continuing students. However, that compromise suggestion of the Government was not quite what the Opposition in the Senate had wished, so there was an amendment put forward by the Opposition and supported by the Democrats that there be a maximum of 15 per cent but that the increase would be determined by regulation each year and would be disallowable. Hence, we have this matter before us now.

I was happy to see that when the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) visited Malaysia and other South East Asian countries she referred to this increase for continuing students as being not a fixed 15 per cent increase, but rather an amount to be determined each year up to a maximum of 15 per cent. When those views had been circulated by a number of us to overseas student groups that eventual second version of the compromise was well received both by those overseas students and Australian students. I have not received any one request-neither has any member of the Opposition-for that proposal to be now upset. It has also been significant that there has been a great deal of concern expressed by those who see great value in the overseas student program in its broadest sense, not only in educational terms but also in foreign affairs and neighbourly relations terms within the region between us in Australia and professional graduates in South East Asia, the Pacific and other countries. I take the opportunity to express again a wide spectrum of concern that the level of these charges should not be increased by this Government beyond that projected in the decision made in the Senate on 28 November.

With regard to the motion for disallowance, there is not only consistency in the Democrats' position in that they were not in favour of any increase at all, but there is also consistency in the fact that by disallowing regulation 2 there would be no increase in any of the charges for the 1986 year. This not only would be disruptive of good administration, but also would not reflect the second version of the compromise to which I have referred and which was the result of the Senate debate last year. It is with those and the other considerations which I have referred to in mind that the Opposition does not support this motion for disallowance. However, I conclude by asking the Government to consider not increasing fees in 1987 for continuing students-understandably, there has not yet been any prediction as to what the level of fee may be-that the full range zero to 15 per cent be taken literally, and that all factors be rationally considered when that level is determined. I ask the Government not to assume that a fixed 15 per cent increase for 1987 would automatically not attract a disallowance motion here in the Senate.

Finally, I also ask the Government to so manage its decisions in this area that the regulation in respect of 1987 be brought to the Parliament much earlier than was the case last year. I think the regulation was promulgated on 19 December. That was some two weeks after the Senate had risen. It is only now, when the Senate has reconvened in the month of February, that we have the ability to consider such a disallowance. Whilst Senator Colston and I have referred to the administrative difficulties which would arise if such a regulation were now disallowed, I ask the Minister for Education to make sure that the Senate has every ability to confirm any regulation or disallow it in good time before any administrative procedures begin for the 1987 year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have just listened to the most extraordinary speech from Senator Teague in which he said that he wants to stand by the point which he made on 28 November. Obviously he did not bother re-reading the speech he made on 28 November. The reason I moved my disallowance motion was that I thought he meant what he said on that day. I will get to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons put forward by the Government seem to me to be correct in terms of the position which it took last year. It is maintaining that position now, fairly obviously, in regard to this regulation. Of course, as Senator Teague rightly pointed out, the Government originally wanted a much higher increase than the increase it has been limited to of 15 per cent. As I pointed out that day, I was under no illusions, regardless of what was said in November that the full 15 per cent would be taken by regulation. We know that that is the type of thing that happens here.

Another reason raised by Senator Colston as to why the Government would not take this on was in regard to higher and second degree students. It is true that my disallowance motion, if carried, and had it not been replaced by the Government on notice of disallowance, in fact would mean a slight increase for those students and a decrease for students undertaking primary degrees. However, the Government had it in its power last year and the year before to rectify that situation, but did not see fit to do so. It seems to me to be crying crocodile tears to be using that as an example this year as to why it should be doing or not doing something.

The last point raised by Senator Colston, which also was raised by Senator Teague, concerned administrative difficulties. There are mechanisms available on notice of disallowance which would allow the Government to withdraw that regulation and put in another regulation which would apply to students this year and would bring fees into line with the inflation rate.

I raise the question of inflation rates because of the extraordinary statements that Senator Teague has just made. I will read what Senator Teague said on 28 November. I thought he was talking then for the Opposition, but I was obviously sadly misled, although he did mention the Opposition on many occasions during his speech. He said:
I must tell the Government that the Opposition regards the 15 per cent rate of increase also as unfair . . .
The Opposition regarded the increase as unfair yet presumably, it is about to vote for it. That is fair enough, but Senator Teague went on to say this:

. . . the Opposition acknowledges that the Government should have the ability to increase the charge but we believe that the appropriate rate of increase in respect of existing students should be the rate of inflation.

What rate of inflation are we looking at? We are looking at a rate of 7.6 per cent-almost half of the 15 per cent increase that the Government requires in its regulation. When I moved my motion for disallowance I was quite confident that I would have the Opposition on side, but no, the Opposition's statements were made obviously for the consumption by overseas students and their journals-a little bit of massaging to make the Opposition feel good. Had the Opposition any intention of doing anything about this matter it would be voting with us to disallow this regulation. It has said one thing in November of last year and is doing another thing in the following year. Senator Teague went on:

Accordingly, our amendment at the Committee stage will propose that the Government determined level of 15 per cent not apply but, rather, that it be the maximum under which the actual rate will be determined each year by regulation so as to reflect generally the rate of inflation in Australia.

I presume Senator Teague thinks the rate of inflation is 15 per cent. He has probably been listening to Mr Howard. Actually, if the honourable senator would like to look it up, the rate of inflation is 7.6 per cent. Senator Teague continued:

Because regulations are subject to disallowance by the Parliament, the Government should expect approval from the Parliament when the rate determined does in fact reflect the annual rate of inflation.

That is what was said in this chamber. Presumably, one could expect to be able to believe what an honourable senator says about subsequent events. On 28 November the Government was put on notice by Senator Teague with regard to what the Opposition would be doing. Foolhardy as I was, I believed him. I now find the very opposite to be the case. Unfortunately, this is a typical example of the type of stuff that is pounded round often in education debates in this place for outside consumption with absolutely no intention of its being followed up. TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the convenience of the Committee would be best served were the Bills to be taken in the following sequence: First, as listed, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill; secondly, its associated measure, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill; thirdly, the Australian Bill of Rights Bill; and, fourthly, its associated measure, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

INTERJECT.PARA: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposed the motion for the second reading of this Bill to establish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I want to make it quite clear that the defeat of this particular measure would not affect the continued operation of the Human Rights Commission. The Opposition's concern about the new Commission, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, is about the very fundamental change in the structure of the Human Rights Commission and the creation of a body which, in our view, will be just another bureaucracy. In other words, the concept of the present Human Rights Commission-to which the Opposition, when in government, gave effect-will be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Human Rights Commission, which has been in existence since 1981, essentially provides advice to Government for the purpose of exercising the obligations the Government assumed when in 1981 it ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The concept was of a small Commission, largely comprising part time people with a particular interest and expertise in human rights questions. The Commission was structured in that way so that it was representative of people who are particularly affected by these issues. The commissioners were selected because of their expertise in human rights matters and several of them had a very personal understanding of some of the problems, particularly of the disabled. It was intended to be serviced by only a small full time staff. The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Commission were full time and there was to be a small staff and a small budget.

Under the Hawke Government in the past three years the staff of the Human Rights Commission has been expanded considerably. Now we have this proposal that it should comprise full time officers. There will be a full time president, a full time race discrimination commissioner, a full time sex discrimination commissioner and at least one other member who may or may not be full time, but I understand from the Government it is intended that he would be full time. I would like the Minister to give some indication of whether the Government's intentions have firmed up, as to who that person will be, who he or she may represent and whether or not he or she will be full time.

The Opposition is concerned that the Commission's character will be changed quite fundamentally by the policy of the Government. Its objection to this Bill is that it will give further and better expression to that major change in policy of the Government towards the Human Rights Commission and the concept it has of the role of that Commission. There is also a very grave and growing concern about the various roles that the Human Rights Commission will be required to assume. That applies to the present Human Rights Commission, regardless of whether or not we have a new Commission.

This Bill will give further emphasis to the various roles of the Commission. It was established originally with the idea of its being an advisory Commission on human rights issues to the government of the day and to the Parliament. It was given various powers, which were seen at that stage to be relevant to that role, but in our view it is now in danger of becoming almost a monster bureaucracy with a lot of powers that would not normally be associated with the bureaucracy. It has a very high and growing administrative bureaucratic role. At the same time it has powers of inquiry, education, conciliation, and trying to settle disputes of various kinds, even under its present charter. If the Bill of Rights is enacted, it will have an even greater role. It now has the power to recommend that damages or compensation be given to people, so it has a semi-judicial role. They are all boxed up in the one body. The Opposition's view is that we need to rethink the situation of the Human Rights Commission, regardless of whether the Bill of Rights is passed or the Commission is converted to a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The existing Human Rights Commission and its powers need to be rethought.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, which is before us to create a new Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, includes in it most of the powers that were given to and are held by the Human Rights Commission. One very significant change relates to the privilege against self-incrimination. I will have more to say about that in the Committee debate on that Bill, when I will move an amendment relating to the power of inquiry by the Commission and the powers to call witnesses, to obtain documents and to examine witnesses on oath. These powers are all set out under Division 3, clause 20, commencing at page 14 of the Bill. In relation to the power to examine witnesses, they may be subpoenaed to appear. They are required to answer questions and they do not have legal representation when they appear before the body, or the person nominated by the body to conduct the inquisition. They are required to answer the questions that are put to them. It is a criminal offence to refuse to answer a question without reasonable excuse.

Clause 24 (3) of the Bill states that a person is not excused from giving any information, producing a document or answering a question on the ground that the information, production of the document or answer might tend to incriminate the person. The information or answer given is not admissable evidence against the person in proceedings other than proceedings for an offence of giving false information to the Commission. That is a very extreme form. I know that there are a lot of precedents for that in modern legislation. The Opposition is becoming more and more concerned about that type of power and the extent of it. We are embarking on a review of our attitude to that type of legislation. Such a power we think is really quite inappropriate in respect of a body of this kind. This sort of draconian power may be justified in company investigation in which one is investigating what is probably more likely to be fraudulent activity. It may be necessary to have such extreme power as that in those circumstances. I think this company investigation precedent, which has been getting widespread use, is particularly inappropriate in human rights legislation. I see no reason in the wide world why the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission should have powers as extensive as that. Section 15 (8) of the existing Human Rights Commission Act deals with this question and states:

It is hereby declared that it is a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse to furnish information or produce a document to answer a question he is asked . . . that the information . . . might tend to incriminate him.

That preserves absolutely the privilege against self-incrimination. The Opposition believes that the restriction on the owner to examine witnesses in the existing Human Rights Commission Act should be incorporated in the new place of legislation.

As I said, we have grave reservations about these general powers as a whole being given to the Commission. However, it is particularly offensive for the power of privilege against self-incrimination to be removed in such an absolute way. We see that as quite inappropriate to a body which is supposed to be the watchdog of a whole lot of guarantees on human rights, including this sort of privilege which is central to, and a major feature of, our criminal justice system. The amendments which I intend to move, and which have been circulated on behalf of the Opposition, involve two matters. One seeks to include a clause which I have already read and the other seeks to amend a clause in the Bill. No doubt we will have further discussion on these matters. However, at this stage I will simply move my amendments and see what the Committee's view is. I seek leave to move the amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 17, clause 23, at end of clause, add the following new sub-clause:

`(3) Without limiting the generality of the expression `reasonable excuse' in this section, it is hereby declared for the avoidance of doubt that it is a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to furnish information, produce a document or answer a question when required to do so under this Act, that the information, the production of the document or the answer to a question might tend to incriminate that person.'.
(2) Page 19, sub-clause 24 (3), leave out sub-paragraph (c) (iii) and paragraph (d).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is dealing with the Bill as a whole and, like Senator Durack, I would like to make a few general comments and ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) one or two questions. Clause 11 of the Bill relates to the functions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and contains a long list of areas where the Commission will have oversight. The Commission will have to inquire and conciliate. It is going to have to report to the Government in relation to acts or practices that may be inconsistent with or contrary to any human right. It is to have research, education and promotion functions. Also, it is going to be able, with the consent of a court, to intervene in proceedings involving human rights issues. I would simply like to echo some concerns about the wide ranging nature of these functions. I ask the Minister whether he can give some explanation of just exactly how the Commission is going to carry out the sorts of general functions that are included in that list. The way in which the Commission is to carry out its investigative and conciliatory functions is set out in considerable detail. However, there is not really a great deal of light cast on how it will go about the research, education and promotion functions.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 27 talks about the requirement of the Commission to give opportunity for the making of submissions. Essentially, the clause says that when the Commission considers that something inconsistent with any human right is done by a person or, presumably, by more than one person, it can give that person the right to make oral or written submissions to the Commission before the Commission reports to the Minister. I recall that during the second reading debate Senator Walters raised the hypothetical situation of somebody whom she referred to as Mrs Ann Citizen who received a rather strong phone call from the Commissioner and was told: `You have had a complaint made against you. We want you to appear before us. No, you cannot have legal representation. Yes, you must attend and you must bring your documents. If you do not, we are going to fine you or throw you in gaol'. I am sure that the Minister remembers vividly that quite horrific story and situation put to us by Senator Walters. I rather imagine that in fact it is not a Mrs Ann Citizen or anyone remotely like her who is likely to be contacted by the Commissioner in that way. At the very most, perhaps, a Mrs Ann Federal Public Servant may well be contacted by the Commissioner and asked to produce documents. In fact, it will not be a citizen who will have those demands made of him or her but a Federal public servant against whom a complaint has been laid for infringement of one of the rights contained in the legislation. I think the Senate and I am sure 16 million Australians would like the Minister to clarify whether the Commissioner or any of the Commissioner's staff will be in a position to ring up individual citizens in their private capacity and say, `Yes, you have to do all of those things', or whether this demand can be made only to somebody against whom a complaint has been made. As I read the Bill, that must be within the confines of the bureaucracy.

The other point I want to raise is the question that has, I guess, been validly put with regard to appeals. I notice that the Minister is not listening to what I am saying. I will just wait until I can get his attention because I think this is an important matter. Apparently there has been a very justified criticism that the Bill itself does not contain a clause similar, for example, to the one contained in the Sex Discrimination Act which allows the Commissioner or the complainant to institute a proceeding in a Federal Court for an order to enforce a determination made by the Commission. As I understand it, when this Bill becomes an Act, a complaint lodged against the behaviour of a Federal public servant can then be investigated by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission using the powers it has under the legislation to call documents and witnesses and to hold compulsory conferences between the parties. The Commission would make a report to the Government and it is then up to the Government to make some sort of decision, presumably through legislation or by way of ministerial directive, to the department concerned with regard to the complaint. Is my reading of section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act correct? It seems to me-and I am quite prepared to be found wrong on this as I am no doubt wrong on other things-that section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 does allow an appeal. The section says:

A reference in this Act to conduct engaged in for the purpose of making a decision includes a reference to the doing of any act or thing preparatory to the making of the decision, including the taking of evidence or the holding of an inquiry or investigation.

Will the AD(JR) Act, section 5, apply to this legislation, therefore giving either of the parties concerned in the dispute the right of appeal to a higher authority, and one, I gather, under which all the rules of evidence and non-allowance of self-incrimination and so on apply? If the Minister could answer those questions I would be appreciative.

The question of general self-incrimination in sub-clause 24 (3) was raised by the Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills, although not terribly enthusiastically. The Committee points out that in this instance the production of the document or the answer to the question is not admissible in evidence except in proceedings for the provision of false or misleading information. That is another category entirely. Although, under the Commission, self-incrimination, or likely self- incrimination, is not an excuse for not furnishing information, any evidence which is produced is not able to be used in any additional proceedings except in the very narrow sense that it is defined. So presumably if an appeal provision was made under the AD(JR) Act it could not be used. As Senator Durack quite rightly pointed out, it is a precedent that has been established with regard to company investigation. I would have thought that bureaucratic investigations should be dealt with in a similar vein if we take malfunctions within the bureaucracy to be at least as serious as malfunctions within a private company; I would have thought that we did. I do not need to say anything more about the general provisions in the Bill except to ask for clarification about whom the Commission can require to attend, and the appeals provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — In developing an accumulating list of things to respond to it might be useful if I come in at this stage and clear at least some of these matters off the desk. As to the general points that were made about the operation of the Commission under the legislation by Senator Durack, and to a lesser extent by Senator Haines, I cannot do much more than refer both of them to the second reading speech given by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the other place and repeated here. The functions of the Commission are there described. Senator Haines asked me how research, education and promotion functions would in fact be exercised by the Commission. I think it is anticipated at this stage that there will not be any significant differences, in principle anyway, as to the way in which these functions are performed by the new Commission as compared with the old. It is a matter for the new Commissioners who will, of course, be primarily, or maybe initially, wholly full time to decide the priorities for the Commission in the light of resources made available to it. Basically, a pattern has been set with the existing Commission and we can reasonably expect that to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the points that Senator Haines made about appeal procedures from the Commission's exercise of its investigative, conciliatory and to a lesser extent determinative functions, yes, it is the case that section 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, will apply to those proceedings and enable them to be appealable through that particular mechanism in the way that Senator Haines was urging should be the case. The Attorney-General has made that perfectly clear and I do not think there is any argument that that should be the case. That is what will be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be some confusion as to whether there is an appeals provision. I just want that clarified. I certainly think there should be. There have been allegations that there is no appeal provision from the determination or the report of the Commission. The Minister has just said that it is there under section 5 the AD(JR) Act 1977.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am making it clear on the record that the review procedure-it is not technically an appeal, but rather a review procedure-is available, is intended to be available and will be available from proceedings of the Commission in that respect. As to the other matter that Senator Haines raised about the extent to which ordinary non-official individuals could be caught up in the Commission's investigative process and required to give evidence, or produce documents, and things of this kind, it is the case that the primary focus of a commission's investigation would be the government agency or the government officials against whom the complaint is made.

SPEECH.PARA: One would reasonably anticipate that the primary focus of these clauses that give certain powers to the Commission to require the production of information would be directed against the officials and the agencies of government concerned rather than any private individual or corporation. Equally, that would be the case in respect of the operation of clause 27 of the Bill which Senator Haines specifically mentioned and which talks in terms of the opportunity being required to be given to make submissions to the Commission. However, it does not follow from that that there is no power in the Commission to require a complainant to produce certain material if the Commission feels that that is appropriate and necessary to get the full dimension of the thing clear.

There is a power in the Commission to identify other witnesses who may be able to assist it in its inquiries. There is a capacity to require them to produce certain kinds of information. One would, of course, expect that power to be exercised very circumspectly and certainly not exercised in relation to persons who are unassociated with the person making the complaint or, from the other point of view, the government agency. One can only, here as elsewhere, expect common sense and discretion to be exercised in the way these institutions actually work. Senator Durack asked me a question about the likely composition of the body. I think it is obviously premature to be too precise about that. Certainly, I have no intention--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not ask for names.

—I did not think the honourable senator was asking for names. It is certainly intended that the President of the Commission be a person of judicial status. That is left open in the legislation and it is discretionary, but it is, as I understand it, the Government's intention that that should be so.
—Will the person be a full time president?

—It is also intended that the person be a full time president. The Bill does make provision for part time commissioners to be appointed. I am not sure of the present intention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in this respect, but certainly the whole reconstituted Commission is being thought of as essentially and primarily a full time body with the part time community input that does exist through the present part time commissioners being better made through a network of advisory and consultative bodies of one kind or another. That is a fluid situation and it may be that the Government's position will change or be adjusted as the circumstances change. I cannot be any more precise than that. I am not unwilling to be precise, I simply cannot be.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the main substance of Senator Durack's amendment, let me say this: The amendment is directed at removing from the Bill the provision in clause 23 which does require a person to answer questions notwithstanding that they may be incriminating, with the very important qualification, of course, that any self-incriminatory evidence so given is inadmissible in any subsequent proceedings other than those for, in effect, perjury. The point should be made that that kind of provision is, as was acknowledged by Senator Durack, by no means unusual in Commonwealth legislation. In fact, we have identified something like 90 instances of it in present Commonwealth statutes.

The reason for putting such a clause in the Bill now before us was in order to maximise the capacity of the Commission to get information, and as comprehensive information as possible, on the matters before it. It should be emphasised here, as elsewhere, that what we are talking about are simply investigative, reporting and conciliation powers of the Commission. We are not talking about the Commission behaving as a court. It cannot impose a penalty on any person. It does not have a dispute settling power involving the making of compulsory orders; it merely makes recommendations.

That all said, obviously it has been the case that very substantial opposition to this measure has been expressed in a number of quarters. I think that a lot of that opposition has been based on a misunderstanding as to the very limited nature of this clause and the context in which it occurs. But, given that it is really just a supplementary power available to the Commission and not one that is, I suppose, strictly necessary in order for it to perform its investigative, conciliation and reporting functions because, as Senator Durack has said, that power is lacking in the present Human Rights Commission and there is no evidence that its functions in this respect have been very seriously hindered by the absence of such a power, I now indicate that the Government will not resist this amendment. In fact, we will not oppose the amendment that Senator Durack has moved.

There are some difficulties about Senator Durack's amendment to clause 24, which I will come back to in a moment. I think that it goes further than simply removing the self-incrimination provision. I am presently looking at the drafting of that. In terms of the proposed deletion of clause 23 (3) and the substitution of the provision that Senator Durack has foreshadowed, I indicate that the Government will not resist that course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gareth Evans for the favourable consideration that he has given to the amendment. I believe that the amendment will improve very much the acceptance of the powers that are to be given to the Commission. I intended the second amendment to be consequential on that amendment. It seemed inevitable that there would have to be changes to clause 24. Whether or not it is necessary to delete sub-paragraphs (c) (iii) as well as paragraph (d) may be the subject of some concern. I am not sure whether that is what is worrying Senator Gareth Evans. By way of explanation I indicate that it was intended to be a consequential amendment.

— I thank Senator Durack for that contribution. I think it might be helpful, under the circumstances, if we were to postpone the consideration of the consequential amendment which Senator Durack has moved in order to ensure that we have the drafting of this right. Perhaps we should deal with the amendment to insert clause 23 (3), return to the Bill at a later hour and untangle the consequential bit.
—With the agreement of the Committee, the amendments will be taken separately.
—This does not preclude discussion on this clause, I take it.
—No. The question before the Chair is that amendments (1) and (2) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In indicating his acceptance of the Opposition's amendment which I support, Senator Gareth Evans has put his finger on what I think is a very important aspect of our approach to this legislation. There is no doubt that there has been a great deal of public concern about the alleged procedures of the Human Rights Commission. Many of those concerns have been unfounded. Many of them have been based on a series of assertions, none of which I have actually seen substantiated by reference to any cases or particular instances. It appears that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is now going to come into being in its new and revised form because of the support which is being given to the proposal by the Australian Democrats. SPEECH.PARA: The question of self-incrimination is, I think, an important one. I think that we are all aware of the provisions of the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution, which provides in part that no person shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself. It is also interesting to consider how the Canadians addressed themselves to this in the original Bill of Rights of 1960, under which they started off their procedure of strengthening human rights legislation in Canada. Section 2 (d) of the Canadian Bill of Rights provided that no law of Canada should be construed in a way which would deny `protection against self-incrimination'. In accepting the amendment which Senator Durack has put forward the Government has come to a realisation that it is important, if this body is to be successful, that it re-establish some degree of public confidence in its procedures, which have been, I think, shaken by a number of unfortunate incidents, some of which the Commission itself is responsible for and for some of which it is not responsible, but which are the result of some ill-informed criticism.

If we are going to get into a situation in which there is a permanent public fight-not so much just criticism, but a permanent public fight-over the procedures of the Commission, that will obscure the more important issue, which is that we should try to build up a public understanding and a degree of public support for measures which protect human rights when they are genuinely under threat. In that respect, I thank the Minister representing the Attorney-General for accepting the Opposition's amendment. I hope that that will set a good precedent for the way in which the remainder of the Committee stage on the four Bills is handled.

Annexure to Address by Deputy Chairman of Human Rights Commission to Administrative Law Seminar
Note of Points Made in Adjournment Speech by the Member for Parkes on 17 September 1985 and Toorak Times Article of 8 September 1985
1. The Commission wishes ``to break down our traditional way of life''. See final point in paragraph 26 of the address.

2. The Commission advocates homosexual immigration. Attention is invited to paragraphs 59-60 of the Commission's Report No. 13 on Human Rights and the Migration Act 1958. There is no advocacy of homosexual immigration, but rather the suggestion that where there is demonstrated and enduring companionship with another person resident in Australia, the overseas person should be allowed to join the companion in Australia. This would include long-time friends and companions as well as homosexual couples.

3. The Queensland Government has been attacked over its electricity supply legislation. The Human Rights Commission found severe breaches of the International Covenant in its Report No. 12 on the Queensland Electricity (Continuity of Supply) Act 1985 and Report No. 14 on the Queensland Electricity supply and Related Industrial Legislation. It found violations of the right to freedom from forced labour, of the right to privacy, of the right to association and of the right to free speech involved in various parts of the Queensland legislation.

4. The International Covenant was ``drawn up by overseas socialist countries''. That is simply untrue. When the Covenants were prepared by the General Assembly in 1966 the Western group had in general terms a majority and indeed there was considerable resistance to the Covenant from communist countries.

5. Irish jokes and Professor Blainey would be outlawed by the racial defamation proposals made in the Commission's Report No. 7. Report No. 7, Proposal for Amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act to Cover Incitement to Racial Hatred and Racial Defamation, is a carefully reasoned document based on a study and increasing numbers of complaints to the Commission. It specifically indicates that the amendments should not cover genuine discussion or reporting of public issues, publication or performance of bona fide works of art and reports of scientific investigation. Both in the report and in subsequent speeches by the Chairman and Deputy Chairman it has been made clear that neither Irish jokes nor the comments of Professor Blainey, whatever their tastefulness, would be caught by the Commission's proposals.

6. The Commission has recommended ``that any illegal immigrant couple who can have a child in Australia be entitled to permanent residence in Australia''. The author of this comment could not have read three of the Commission's reports which address the issue-No. 10 on the Human Rights of Australian Born Children: Report on the Complaint of Mr and Mrs R. C. Au Yeung; No. 13 on Human Rights and the Migration Act 1958 and No. 8 on Deportation and the Family: A report on the Complaints of Mrs M. Roth and Mr C. J. Booker. In each of these the Commission explains that it does not oppose deportation but that after a person has been here for a substantial length of time, e.g. five years or more, and has integrated in the community and in the meantime has had a child who by Australian law becomes a citizen, the balance of human rights tends to move towards retaining the family rather than deporting the family including the child. The alternative specifically commended to the Government for consideration is that, as in the United Kingdom, children born in Australia should only receive citizenship automatically if they are born to citizens or permanent residents. There is no invitation to circumvention of the law-rather, to apply the existing law humanely or to change it.

7. Criticism of the Queensland community services legislation. In its Report No. 9, Community Services (Aborigines) Act 1984, the Commission commended the forward steps taken by the Queensland Government in relation to Aborigines living on reserves, but made the point that some of the changes still leave Aboriginal communities in a deprived situation, e.g. in relation to voting for local government and control of affairs on their land. The Commission encouraged further action.

8. The right of Women Against Rape to march on Anzac Day. The Commission has made no formal pronouncement on this subject but has drawn attention to the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and indicated that in such situations there should be no arbitrary prevention of particular groups joining processions.

9. The proposed Bill of Rights would confer ``alarming powers'' on the Commission. That is manifestly untrue. The proposals for a Bill of Rights contain no change in the present carefully drawn powers conferred on the Commission to investigate complaints and hold inquiries on human rights matters. As to the Star Chamber, see address, paragraph 25, point 3.

10. The Commission has advertised ``offering bribes to school teachers''. This is the most extraordinary piece of misinformation. The Commission advertised Australia-wide for teachers interested in receiving small grants to enable experimental use of its teaching materials ``Teaching for Human Rights''. All over Australia teachers are using the kit and are evaluating it with a view to re-issue in a form taking account of the outcome of the evaluation. Only the Queensland Government school system has been banned, by the Queensland Minister for Education, from using the kit which has otherwise received favourable comment from teachers and pupils in government, independent and Catholic school systems.

11. A report by Dr Moens has been ``suppressed''. The Commission for legal reasons has not made public the reasons for its dissatisfaction. However, it has indicated to Dr Moens that he is free to publish his work. It may be worth noting that that has not occurred. The Commission would not spend public funds publishing material that failed in almost all significant respects to conform with contract requirements.

12. The Commission is alleged not to have investigated a complaint from Mr Erwin Chlanda. The Commission received complaints from Mr Chlanda, but on investigation found nothing to indicate that his race was the reason why Aboriginal organisations were unwilling to deal with him. While the Commission, following its practice where there is no jurisdiction, has not proceeded with the complaints, its staff have discussed Mr Chlanda's difficulties with him and through their good offices have been seeking to help him open communication with Aboriginal organisations.

13. Criticism of Wollongong University. It was not the Commission, but the Deputy Chairman who drew attention to a challenge by the University in the High Court to a finding of racial discrimination by the Equal Opportunity Tribunal of New South Wales. The criticism was based on the fact that the ground of the appeal was not on substance of the matter but a technical Constitutional point in relation to racial discrimination, which is made unlawful by legislation of both the Commonwealth and New South Wales.

14. The Commission has abandoned ``traditional concepts of Justice''. This is too vague an accusation to answer except by saying that on no occasion has the Commission abandoned the pursuit of justice or of human rights and that it has rarely used the powers it has been given by the Parliament, and then only with care and without resorting to enforcement measures. It has assumed no powers as appears to be alleged.

15. The Commission is selective in deciding what cases it will take up and has not examined alleged incitement against people of German extraction. The Commission has invited the person making this criticism (Mr John Bennett) to give a specific case to investigate, but he has failed to do so.

16. The Commission is not interested ``in the rights of the 75% of the population of Anglo Saxon Celtic origins''. The Commission is interested in the rights of all people in Australia and, when they are threatened, will unhesitatingly defend them. The Racial Discrimination Act is available for anyone in Australia, and the Commission investigates with equal care the not infrequent complaints it receives from people who would identify as ``Anglo-Saxon-Celtic''. Naturally, many of its reports will deal with the problems of minority groups. But such reports as those relating to the A.C.T. Mental Health Ordinance, the Australian Citizenship Act, the Commonwealth Crimes Act, the Human Rights of the terminally ill and the Migration Act deal with important issues of considerable interest to all people in Australia, including those who may have their origins in the United Kingdom and Ireland.

With regard to Senator Harradine's contribution, I take on board what he said about cross fertilisation of ideas and experience, and the need for the Commission not to become isolated, remote and overburdened with administrative detail at the expense of keeping track of currents of opinion in the community at large. I think this is an evolutionary thing and the Government's response will be based very much on its reading of the experience of the Commission during its early days. I will certainly ensure that Senator Harradine's views on this matter are communicated to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). No firm or final decisions have been made about the structure of the Commission. There is a capacity to appoint part timers. A number of senators have made this point during the course of the debate and I draw those considerations to the Attorney's attention so that he can give them such weight as he feels appropriate.

As to the argument about the educative role of the Commission, I acknowledge that controversy will always erupt from time to time about particular projects in which the Commission engages but I do think it is a little unfair that Ralph Pettman's teaching instruction kit should have attracted quite the storm of extravagant criticism--

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially when he is getting curry from the USSR.

—I think that point needs to be put on the record in this Parliament. We have had Senator Short and Senator Harradine, and no doubt in a moment we will hear from Senator Boswell who has been rushing out to gird his loins with more extravagant denunciations.
—It is only two paragraphs.
—What we are talking about is just two paragraphs, as Senator Missen has said, in a very large publication which has won general acclaim for its balance and perception--
—Except from the USSR.

—Except, as Senator Haines rightly points out, in the USSR. One can imagine why because immediately preceding a rather exuberant reference to the iniquities, in some people's view, of the capitalist system-a paragraph which has been very widely quoted and which has given rise to suggestions that this is just a handbook for the communist millennium--
—That was not my point.

—No, the honourable senator's will come in a moment. The honourable senator should just curb his racing hormones. We will get to the family in a moment. Immediately prior to a reference to the construction of a capitalist world economy predicated upon dishonesty and greed, which I understand has jangled a few nerves on the other side of this chamber, we have the following language:

SPEECH.PARA: More than twice the numbers who died in the Holocaust, for example, were killed in constructing the modern Soviet state.

That is a pretty explicit sort of proposition and it is enough to jangle the nerves of any commissar worth his salt in the Kremlin. Indeed, those nerves have been jangled and this particular publication has been roundly denounced, as a result, by the very czars of communism who are supposed to be so ecstatic about this particular publication. So it is balanced. It is balanced throughout in its more moderate mode, and in its more extravagant mode it is also balanced as well.

As to the reference to the family, which is the one other paragraph in this entire booklet seems to have attracted a great deal of enthusiasm, again I think it is unfortunate that the whole context in which that paragraph occurs has not been read out. It occurs in a section about the family, the opening bars of which is a reference to Article 16 (3) of the Universal Declaration; namely, that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society. That is followed by the comment:
Bedrock unit it may well be; but it is not immune from the forces that shape society itself.
After further comment of that kind we come to the offending paragraph. It states:

In Australia-a liberal, capitalist, multicultural democracy, with social welfare proclivities, a high stratified class structure, a value system that is secular, racist, sexist and materialistic-the family reflects and promotes this fact.

All that is being said-and it is, no doubt, a controversial judgment; sociologists are capable of controversy about anything-is that the family is part of the larger currents that shape and, in turn, are shaped by society. These values, whether we like them or not, are prevalent in this society of ours and it is to be expected, as a result, that one would find these values flowing through and being part of the make up of some of the constituent fundamental units of that society. That is all that is being said. It goes on to qualify even that assertion by saying:

The picture is far from static or clear, however. Quite the contrary. As our society has changed, so, in symbiotic fashion, has this `fundamental group unit' . . . Mum, Dad and the Kids (plus assorted `rellies') has never been adequate as a description of the Australian family, though it has been very powerful in defining expectations in this regard.

That is the context in which the discussion jogs along. It is not an assertion in capital letters and neon lights that the Australian family is sexist, racist and materialistic, implying the assumption or justifying the inference that the family ought no longer to be supported, which is the kind of inference that, with the utmost respect to him, Senator Harradine has been a little bit anxious to extract from those words.

I will not continue the debate although I fear that others might be minded to. I simply make the point that one can argue about language such as this that appears in booklets such as this, but part of the function of such booklets is to generate argument and response from kids in schools who are coming to grips with these kinds of issues. I do not say this about all its reports, some of which I have vigorously disagreed with, but the educative material being produced by the Human Rights Commission has, I think, been very good indeed, acknowledged as such, and not justifying the kind of assault that has been made upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister whether he has seen the full kit put out on education.

—If he has seen the kit, he will know that there is an accompanying smaller booklet giving advice to teachers. —I would be interested to know whether it has been altered, but in the accompanying booklet that I received from the Human Rights Commission the advice to teachers was that within the first three months of a child being in the classroom all the problems that have developed at home must be overcome. —This sounds like a version of the Jesuits: Give me a child before--
—Yes, it really does. The first three months have got to be used as a brainwashing process to get rid of all the--
—I would like to see the prose--

—I will bring it for Senator Evans. I thought he said he had seen the full kit. He may not have read it all. —It is the major document.

—Senator Missen says he is looking only at the major document. That might be very good. I believe that the videos that come with it are excellent. I believe that the majority of the book is excellent. I agree with that. There is only a small area of that book with which I would disagree but, for goodness sake, we should look at everything that is handed out. Senator Missen says: `I am only looking at the major document'. That is not the correct thing to do. If a person is going to have a good look at it, he should look at the lot.
—I did not say that. I said that is the major document.

—The honourable senator should not look only at the major document; he should look at the lot. I am asking honourable senators to look at the advice that has been given to the teachers because I think that it is pretty dangerous. Honourable senators ought to look at this document. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, am concerned with the powers given to the Human Rights Commission. I ask the Minister to justify, on behalf of the Human Rights Commission, the great amount of money that was spent by the Commission to put on a Priority One concert. Is that in the terms of reference of the Human Rights Commission? What other public relations exercises can the Commission run, and what will be the cost of them, to give the Commission a bit of publicity and build up its image? As the Minister said before, the Human Rights Commission has got a public relations problem. It is a very grave problem because this Parliament is going to give it carte blanche to investigate and report on all States, local government and councils.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable senators have referred to some indiscretions that the Human Rights Commission has perpetrated on the public of Australia. Senator Walters brought up such a case; Senator Short brought up one yesterday in a question to the Minister and Senator Harradine has voiced his concern. Even the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hurford, has said he has lost confidence in the Human Rights Commission. We could go on with a whole dialogue of things that the Human Rights Commission has done, including throwing the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Neil Brown, out of its offices and putting a ban on him. TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot remember that bit. Tell us about it.
—Let me read it to the Minister. I think it bears repeating in the Senate. This is Mr Pettman's resume of Sleeping Beauty:

SPEECH.PARA: The King in Sleeping Beauty organises the party and the guest list (the Queen is not consulted). Indeed, all decisions are invariably made by males, and in times of crisis, the most typical reaction by female characters is to fall down crying.
