SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the response by Senator Evans to various criticisms of the Human Rights Commission which Senator Haines, other senators and I have made. We have said that the Human Rights Commission has too many functions that are somewhat in conflict and confuse the powers of investigation with the powers of conciliation and determination. I was pleased to hear Senator Evans say that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is considering the establishment of a human rights tribunal to exercise, under various statutes, the powers of determination or recommendation, or those powers which are of a determinative or policy making kind. It is the first time that I have heard any suggestion from the Government that this is what it has in mind. I am anxious to investigate this matter somewhat further.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate that has been going on about the Human Rights Commission for a long time, and in the light of the very great concerns that have been expressed and the misunderstandings that have been held and encouraged about the Human Rights Commission, there has been a justifiable thread of concern that this body has some indications of a new grand inquisition. There is substance in that concern. As the Minister who was responsible for introducing this potential monster, in the eyes of many people, I have given the matter a great deal of thought and attention. As I said earlier, the Opposition is reviewing its whole attitude to this matter.

I am pleased that the Government, from what Senator Evans said, has some recognition of this basic problem of the way the Human Rights Commission has been structured and the way that it has had function after function added to it and the powers it has. The end result is that we have a body which needs to be rethought. I hope that this was not just a throw-away line from the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) who represents the Attorney-General, but that the Government is seriously looking at restructuring the Commission to allay the very real concerns of many people, that this body, if it has not already got out of hand, could well get out of hand, particularly if it gets the very much increased jurisdiction which the Bill of Rights will give it. I have in mind the extension of its jurisdiction to the States and to the investigation of acts and practices of State governments and officials, which will greatly widen the jurisdiction and powers of the Human Rights Commission under its existing legislation.

Whatever the final determinations may be-there are a variety-they are not all characterised as judicial or semi-judicial. For instance, under this legislation and the Bill of Rights the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission ultimately can make recommendations-it cannot discipline or place any penalty on the public official or officials who may be the subject of an investigation, as it can under the Sex Discrimination Act-or reports which could be so critical of the conduct of an official that it could be the end of that official's career, apart from the publicity of a finding. Although it cannot make determinations of the ordinary judicial or semi-judicial kind, it can make findings which could be highly damaging to individuals. The mere fact that they happen to be public servants of Federal or State governments is quite beside the point. They have human rights as much as any other member of the Community.

This Commission, with the new powers it will have under this legislation, can recommend that damages or compensation be paid to a complainant. One may say that that is just the Government having to pay, it is not the official or an ordinary individual having to pay, so why worry about it. But the payment of compensation has to be looked at generally, as to what sorts of compensations people get for various injuries or detriments they suffer under the legal system. If the Human Rights Commission recommends payment of a certain sum of money, it would be very difficult for the Government not to adopt that recommendation to pay. Yet it might be a quite ridiculous sum of money, having no regard whatever to what people can recover for very serious personal injuries, damage to reputation or whatever. To leave that function, which could be very harmful to some people and overgenerous to others, to a group such as the members of the Human Rights Commission-which will largely comprise people who have this particular interest, without having regard to the wider community scene-could be quite dangerous. Therefore, the idea of restructuring the Commission in the way Senator Evans suggested that the Attorney-General is looking at, could be a way of overcoming a lot of the concerns about this Human Rights Commission and the way it will develop inevitably under the legislation we are not considering, if it becomes law.

This legislation-apart from the Bill of Rights Bill, which is a separate matter-will become law in the very near future. I welcome that and I hope we will hear more from the Government about it. I am indeed surprised that we have not heard from the Attorney-General about it. I wonder how coherent he would be if he were asked a question about what he is doing? I hope that perhaps Senator Evans and some of his colleagues will be able to ensure that the Parliament and the public are informed what work is being done and how soon we are likely to have a very considerable restructuring.

I am just amazed that such an important matter as this has never been mentioned in the debate that has been going on now for 12 months or more. Although a whole new Commission is being set up and the Government has a human rights package, there has been no word or suggestion until today that the Government is really acknowledging this problem and is planning to do something about it. I would have thought that this would have been part of the package. Although I am disappointed that nothing has been done, I hope that the Government is genuine in its intention to move along these lines and do something.

I want to ask the Minister for Resources and Energy, who is at the table, a question arising out of an answer he gave in the Senate yesterday about the way in which the Government is going to use the new Commission when it is established shortly. Probably most of us remember that Senator Evans said, in answer to a question asked by Senator Black, that the question of the undemocratic State electoral laws, whatever State it may be, `will be the subject of an early reference to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission' which will replace the existing body. He went on to say:
Depending upon the report of that new Commission finding State laws to be in conflict with the guarantees in the Bill of Rights, which may not be a totally unlikely outcome--
that is, Senator Evans is forecasting the report of the Commission not to be totally unlikely-I suppose that is an euphemism for saying: `We expect the Commission to give us the report that we want'-
the Commonwealth will give the States an opportunity to bring their laws into compliance. If such legislative action is not forthcoming the Commonwealth will then enact overriding legislation . . .

It is interesting to note that this Government will shortly appoint the members of this Commission. Does that mean that the Government is going to have an eye on the likely outcome of this report when it appoints the members of the Commission? I think that that is a very real concern that we should have. Maybe Senator Evans would like to say something about that.

I am also concerned whether the statement of policy is a precedent for the way in which the Government intends to use the package of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Bill of Rights. Clearly Government supporters and back benchers are obsessed about this matter. Of course, the Australian Democrats are exerting great pressure as well. The Government has obviously reacted to that immediate pressure.

Obsessions have been held from time to time about certain State laws, particularly the law regarding the right of assembly. The Bill of Rights will contain a guarantee that every person has the right of peaceful assembly. If some pressure is placed on the Government in respect of the assembly laws in a particular State-I do not need to mention any particular State and there is no prize for guessing which State I am referring to-would the Commission be asked for a report? If the Government received a report which said that a particular State law does not give effect to the provisions of the Bill of Rights, does the Government intend to follow the same precedent that Senator Evans says it will follow? What immediate use will the Government make of this new Commission?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I would just like to make a couple of comments and ask a couple of questions in regard to some remarks that were made earlier by Senator Gareth Evans. I apologise that I did not hear all that he said, but my attention has been drawn to some of his remarks. I understand that Senator Evans said that some of the criticisms that have been made about the human rights teaching kit, that has been the focus of attention in this chamber and elsewhere in the last couple of days, are unfounded and essentially were taken out of context. I think an important point needs further consideration. A key factor in the operation of the whole package of this legislation, if passed, will be, as Senator Durack said, the new Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Basically, this Commission will be a major expansion of the present Human Rights Commission. The prestige of that Commission is of critical importance in terms of the credibility-if there is going to be any credibility at all-and confidence that the community will be able to place on the administration of the legislation that is before us. Therefore, it is essential that the community feels confident about the existing Commission from which the new Commission will flow.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise again with Senator Evans the two key paragraphs in the education kit-there are more-that have been referred to in the last few days. I refer to that section of the kit dealing with life and the section dealing with the family. I think it is worthwhile and important to repeat those paragraphs. The paragraph in the chapter on life states:

There has been mass assassination, too, by more covert and indirect means. The construction of a capitalist world economy, predicated upon dishonesty and greed, has slaughtered uncounted millions the world over through the exploitation and the mis-development of global resources. The United States and the other erstwhile `free market' democracies have much to answer for in this regard.
The other paragraph which has been the subject of such attention refers to the family and states:

In Australia-a liberal, capitalist, multicultural democracy, with social welfare proclivities, a highly stratified class structure, a value system that is secular, racist, sexist, and materialistic-the family reflects and promotes this fact.

I ask Senator Evans whether those two paragraphs can be read in context or not. Let me take the paragraphs one at a time. The first contains a bald statement that the capitalist world economy is predicated on dishonesty and greed and has been the cause of mass assassination of uncounted millions the world over. There is no way at all that that statement, in context or out of context, can be described as anything other than hard core communist propaganda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know that that is the reason why the Human Rights Commission is going to have that revised in the next edition?

—Well, that may be fine. This document has been out in the schools for a year or so now. It is too late to revise it. I acknowledge that it has to be revised, but the paragraphs to which I have referred should never have appeared. The document is biased in the extreme. Even reading the whole document in context, it does not present a balanced view of a part of our society. It does not present another view. It is not even-handed and it is not objective. I believe it is abhorrent and totally contrary to the values of this society. I would say exactly the same about aspects of the paragraph on the family. Does Senator Evans agree with these statements regardless of their context? Does the Government agree with those statements? If the Minister and the Government do agree then they stand condemned; if they do not I believe they have a fundamental obligation to demand that that literature be withdrawn, revised and looked at very carefully before it is, in whatever form, recirculated. If this is not done the credibility of the Commission that the Government is relying on to administer this great socialist mass of legislation will have even less credibility than it has at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is unfortunate that Senator Short missed my earlier contribution because I think I did indicate that I thought perhaps some of the language employed in particular paragraphs that have come into issue was a little extravagant, but it is important to appreciate the context in which they occur. To describe a passage like that as hard core communist propaganda, when it is immediately preceded by a sentence which says `More than twice the numbers who died in the Holocaust, for example, were killed in constructing the modern Soviet state', is, I think, to put just a little more of a gloss on the material than it deserves and justifies. I do not want to prolong this particular argument; we have all made our positions clear. For the record, I would appreciate if the Senate would give me leave to incorporate in Hansard the full passages under `Life' and `The Family' headings respectively in which those two offending paragraphs appear so that any readers or posterity can judge for themselves the points that I was making earlier on about context in which Senator Short so obviously disagrees with me about. I seek leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The passages read as follows-
LIFE

The Universal Declaration was devised in direct response to the appalling events of World War II, and Article 3 begins: `Everyone has the right to life . . .' The point of this particular principle was to oppose the sort of ideologies and institutions that make wars happen, and in the course of them can systematically murder six million Jews, Slavs, and Gypsies.

Genocide-the deliberate attempt to exterminate whole peoples-is not new. However, the technology of our age has made this possible on a completely new scale and ruthless regimes of both the left and right have not been slow in using the tools that the contemporary world has made available to kill those they see as in the way. More than twice the numbers who died in the Holocaust, for example, were killed in constructing the modern Soviet state.

There has been mass assassination, too, by more covert and indirect means. The construction of a capitalist world economy, predicated upon dishonesty and greed, has slaughtered uncounted millions the world over through the exploitation and the mis-development of global resources. The United States and the other erstwhile `free market' democracies have much to answer for in this regard.

Meanwhile, like Nemesis, there hangs over all the daily threat of thermo-nuclear suicide. Asserting the `right to life' has taken on a meaning it has never had before. The extinction of the entire species is imminent daily.

There is much here to discuss and understand. On one level, it is a matter of the utmost urgency that people be made aware of the implications of what could be done at the touch of a button-in their ostensible defence-by regimes that control immense armories of the most terrifying weapons imaginable. On another level, people die in large numbers daily from exploitation. This is not incidental. It is actively perpetrated by people who control world production to their own profit, rather than the good of mankind (especially those most in need). On another level again, innocent people in a large number of contemporary states are harassed daily by politicians, police and the military. These leaders demand obedience and are prepared to maim and kill to get it.
This is strong stuff. However, as Ned Kelly is supposed to have said before he was hanged: `Such is life'.
THE FAMILY
The family, Article 16 (3) of the Universal Declaration proclaims, `is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State'.

Bedrock unit it may well be; but it is not immune from the forces that shape society itself. Indeed, the family typically takes the form relevant to the socio-economic and cultural realities of the larger community it lies within. At the same time, of course, it plays its own part in conditioning them. Thus, hierarchically arranged societies manifest patterns of family power of a similar sort. Egalitarian societies typically manifest more equal familiar relationships. And vice versa.

In Australia-a liberal, capitalist, multicultural democracy, with social welfare proclivities, a highly stratified class structure, a value system that is secular, racist, sexist, and materialistic-the family reflects and promotes this fact.

The picture is far from static or clear, however. Quite the contrary. As our society has changed, so, in symbiotic fashion, has this `fundamental group unit'. The conventional Anglo-bourgois model of Mum, Dad, and the Kids (plus assorted `rellies') has never been adequate as a description of the Australian family, though it has been very powerful in defining expectations in this regard.

Aboriginal Australians, with the elaborate kinship systems intrinsic to Aboriginal culture, have never sat happily within the imperial framework. Nor have many of those who came after them. The mass immigration of the last few generations has meant, among other things, the importation of a wide range of multicultural family forms. However, given the highly assimilationist nature of the dominant Anglo-culture, these, like those of Aboriginal Australians, have never received much official recognition. They continue to flourish-more or less modified-nonetheless.

Meanwhile, the conventional model as defined in Anglo-Celtic terms has become progressively less accurate as an account of conventional behaviour. The effects of secular individualism have taken a heavy toll, and modifications to the monocultural version now abound. For example, in terms of human rights, there is no ideal form of the family. There is only the decree that governments should protect families, and those who live therein. Unless one has a prior conception of what the family ought to be, and applies this regardless (a distinctly totalitarian approach), a wide range of current familial forms justify governmental recognition in the promotion and protection of this fundamental right. There are, in other words, a number of group units that people find `natural' and `fundamental' in the performance of familial functions, and if Article 16 (3) is to be given a fair go, governments are obliged to acknowledge and allow for this fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I say in response to Senator Short that I agree with him that it is important that the community have confidence in the Commission and its successor body, confidence in its judgment and sensitivity to the sorts of issues it is dealing with, but I also make the point that I do not think that community confidence is enhanced when one gets assaults being made upon the Commission for, it must be acknowledged, essentially short term political objectives by opponents of the Government. I do not think it helps if assaults are made in the very extravagant language that has been employed without regard to what can be said for the other side of the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to Senator Boswell's contribution on a similar theme. I acknowledge that, taken in isolation the passage about Sleeping Beauty might attract a few sniggers or even a degree of indignation in Senator Boswell's breast. But then again I think it has to be acknowledged that Little Black Sambo and gollywogs are probably still alive and well in the Queensland hinterland. It is unfortunate that people do not appreciate sensibly the perfectly rational arguments that can be made about the way in which sexist and racial values inherent in a great deal of nineteenth century children's literature, and indeed twentieth century children's literature, have become so much a part of our culture that we adults perhaps do not notice it. It is a great and recurring theme of children's literature studies these days about the way in which values like these appear. I think perfectly sensible points and discussions can be generated about these matters without being the subject of caricature in the way they were by Senator Boswell.

I am indebted to Senator Durack for his support for the concept that I sketched about the desirability of separating out determining functions from the other sorts of functions exercised by human rights bodies. I am little surprised by his surprise at the apparent innovativeness of all this. It is a theme that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), as I recall, himself advanced in an important speech he made at the University of New South Wales, last December, I think on Human Rights Day. Certainly it was a theme that recurred in a number of my speeches as Attorney-General in the first two years we were in government, although I appreciate that Senator Durack did not necessarily regard them as his favourite bedtime reading. I think it might have been desirable if we had been able to advance consideration of this a bit further and bring it forward as part of a single passage, but I assure the honourable senator that it is something the Government is giving close attention to and I hope the Government will be in a position to make some appropriate announcement soon. I commend the Bill at the Committee stage to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise today is one of great concern to all Australians who have insurance policies which they believe cover their houses and their possessions. The point I want to raise is that indeed those people are not covered in an important contingency. I am distressed to find from feedback from voters I have had in the last week or two since I first raised this matter in Perth that most of them are not aware that indeed nuclear exclusion clauses have for some time existed in their insurance policies. I believe they are also not aware of the enormous extent of these exclusions. For instance, I quote from a New South Wales Government Insurance Office householder's policy, in fact a policy on my own house:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the policy does not cover loss or damage to property or any legal liability directly or indirectly caused by or contributed to, or arising from ionising radiation or contamination from any nuclear fuel or from any nuclear waste or from the combustion of nuclear fuel.

That is followed by a clause in that policy which makes all the same points in relation to nuclear weapons material. It has been confirmed by the major insurance companies to the media, certainly in Perth, where I raised this matter some little time ago, that that is virtually the case with almost all, if not all, insurance policies in Australia. So we have the appalling situation where literally millions of people who think that they are covered against all contingencies in their comprehensive household insurance are not, in fact, covered against that one and have not been for some time.

The situation is even worse, because on my understanding-and I will be addressing a question on this matter later this day hopefully to the responsible Minister-the Federal Government does not accept any liability on this matter and has not required those countries which send nuclear ships into this country to accept any liability. Indeed, there have been statements by the United States that it accepts only a limited liability in the case of any kind of accident that would happen elsewhere in the world where people's property is concerned. I raise the matter in the Senate because it is a matter of great seriousness. It has been raised before; I raised it myself six or seven years ago in this place and I got undertakings at that time for the insurance industry and others that something was going to be done about it. In fact, as I understand it, nothing has been done about it; it has been put into the too hard drawer. The only thing that has changed in recent years, of course, is that the Australian Government has accepted a principle that it will admit nuclear powered and nuclear armed warships of any foreign power it chooses into the ports of the city. It is also a fact that Garden Island in Sydney, the major naval base, is right smack in the middle of the city. That contingency, that circumstance, that the Government is prepared to let those ships in at any time, I believe, places an additional obligation on the Government to get this matter right. It is not good enough that it should say that these ships should come here; that it accepts the fact that the insurance companies, for their own reasons-and it is most interesting that the insurance companies did this-have excluded themselves quite consciously and deliberately from any cost factor involved in a nuclear accident; that the Government is not prepared to do anything itself and will not consult with the States; and that, as far as I know, it has not got any kind of firm, definite undertaking from those people who send nuclear ships here that they will accept the liability as well.

It is a cause for added concern that these nuclear exclusion clauses specifically exclude damage caused even indirectly or only contributed to by nuclear means. I am looking now at giving notice of motion in the Senate at some time in the not too distant future to raise this matter so that it can be publicly debated and some solution to it found, because I believe that the Government has been very much remiss in not making a full examination of the situation so that action can be taken in association with the States, perhaps with the insurance industry and certainly with those people who send ships here.

Because of the frequency of nuclear ship visits to Perth this matter, of course, must be of the greatest concern to Western Australians. But as more and more ships come in, because of the Government's policy, perhaps into Sydney, Jervis Bay or any Australian port, that situation is going to cause enormous hardship to millions of people and literally take everything they possess out of their hands; their major assets would be destroyed or so damaged that they could not be used without any reason.

Let us assume, for instance, that there was a radiation leak, even quite a minor one, from the reactors, say, in a nuclear submarine, which uses very highly enriched uranium-in fact, it is not commonly known but it is a fact that it uses weapons grade enriched uranium in its reactors-at Garden Island in Sydney. On any summer afternoon, with the usual north-easter blowing, that would involve contamination for a lengthy period and the necessity for an evacuation of the entire city centre of Sydney and the most closely populated residential area in Australia. All those people living in that area in home units, houses and flats and working there in their shops would have to evacuate that area. There is no doubt about that whatsoever. That could result from quite a small accident to a reactor-not an explosion but something on a much smaller scale. Those people, as the law stands now and as the Government's attitude stands now, would have to leave that area. They have no recourse whatsoever; they would not get a cent in compensation from anybody, as I understand the situation. If I am in error, let the Government say so. I am only too willing to have that said, but I want the situation straightened out.

A further scenario that could involve actual damage as well as contamination also, of course, exists. There is no need to canvass the likelihood of either of these contingencies. That is beside the point. It is enough to say that they are possible, and indeed of course they are possible. Modern technology is very subject to unexpected problems. We thought, we were told, that the space shuttle technology was perfect and that there was no way in the world it could fail, but it did fail, and failed tragically, with the Challenger, as we know only too recently. Nuclear technology is no different; it has failed from time to time in controllable circumstances in reactors which are on-shore.

Ship reactors are a very different kettle of fish. Ship reactors, because of requirements of weight and so on, have to be made to much finer tolerances. They are devices which certainly in the past, as far as we know, have given good service. We would not be told, I think if they had not. They are made to fine tolerances. They are delicate instruments. They use very heavily enriched uranium, especially in submarines, and they do present a risk which is real.

The Government must act in this matter. It must either accept full liability itself for any accident that might occur-we are speaking now, of course, of literally billions and billions of dollars of damage that could be the result of quite a small accident in a highly built-up area-or insist that any country that sends a nuclear ship to any port in Australia accepts beforehand absolute, complete and total liability for any damage that might be caused by its ship, for any reason whatsoever, while it is in Australian waters. The Government wants that iron clad. It must be done by treaty, and it must be an absolute legal commitment by those countries concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of public importance at the moment that the public should be advised of what is really happening to the economy. There has been a whole series of Government targets for various areas of economic activity. The Government has assured the people of Australia, for example, that it will maintain the strong growth that has taken place over the last few years-growth, of course, that was built, first, on the breaking of the drought and stimulated to an extent by some Government spending which the rest of Australia had to pay for. The Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in particular, have insisted that this growth will be sustained. We have seen claims that the trilogy will be met. We are not quite certain what the trilogy is because the grounds appear to be continually changing, but there is an assurance that the trilogy will be met. There is also the assurance that the balance of payments deficit revised target for the year will be met and that everything is all right. As I think the song from South Pacific says, the Government is indulging in `happy talk'.

SPEECH.PARA: What on earth should the people of Australia believe, particularly when one of the other major undertakings which related to reducing interest rates is now, of course, no longer sustainable? No matter how much the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tries to blame individual banks for what is happening, there is no doubt that the Government itself, through its own policies, has destroyed its claimed objective of reducing interest rates. When the Government itself is paying enormous interest rates to raise money, the Government itself is pushing up interest rates. Of course, we all know that that is the situation. When a government has a discount rate of 18 per cent to 19 per cent, obviously it is a major element in the high interest rates.

There are areas where, in fact, the Government is paying more for money-and the Government is, after all, the most gilt-edged of all borrowers-than some commercial borrowers. For anyone in the Government to pretend that in that circumstance it is not the Government's fault that interest rates are high is absolute, politically-oriented nonsense and an attempt to get out of a clear responsibility for what is happening.

On all these scores we have every right to ask: What is the Government doing? Mr Hawke has insisted, as I mentioned earlier, that we are going to see a continuation of the growth rate. Of course, that is necessary if the Government is to continue to meet its objectives in employment. There is no doubt that the reason that the Government has been able to create an environment in which so many new jobs have been created in the last few years has been this fast rate of economic growth. That, as we can see, has been bought at the cost of Australia's balance of payments, record deficits, rising interest rates, and increasing inflation. In fact, a temporary rise in employment has been bought at the long term cost of the Australian economy and at the long term cost of employment itself.

I think the Australian people have every right to wonder what is happening next. As I understand it, Mr Bob White of the Westpac Banking Corporation, yesterday in a speech in Surfers Paradise forecast that if interest rates keep going the way they are economic growth in Australia this calendar year will fall from around 5 per cent to 2 to 2.5 per cent. It will be halved. I would think that that is a reasonable expectation. That will, as I said, have an immense impact on employment; it will involve a substantial increase in unemployment and it will make the temporary figures that the Government has been boasting on the employment front look as sick as they really are.

The question of the trilogy, of course, is an absolute farce. I think the Sydney Morning Herald headline today-`Hawke fudges deficit pledge'-says everything; that is, Mr Hawke keeps changing his Government objectives whenever it becomes evident that they cannot be achieved. We saw the Treasurer, for example, keep changing the monetary targets until he dropped them. He kept changing them when it was clear that the monetary targets would not be met. We have seen the Treasurer changing the balance of payments target from $10.7 billion to $11.25 billion when at last, after continual nagging in this chamber, it had to be admitted by the Government that there was no prospect of meeting this Budget target for the current account deficit and the balance of payments. Whenever there is any pressure on any of these governmental targets, which are really no more than soft soap, these promises by the Government which simply cannot be met, they get revised out ultimately and there is a hope that the public will forget that the Government has once again deliberately sought to deceive the people of Australia, when there is no chance of these targets actually being met.

I will deal at greater length with the balance of payments target because that is the one under most immediate threat at the moment, although of course I also accept that the Budget deficit target, as we originally understood it, is under direct and immediate threat as well. We have many more figures available to demonstrate to us the falseness of the Government's pretending to stick to the $11.25 billion current account deficit on the balance of payments which it set late last year and, as I said, revised upwards from $10.7 billion.

Let us look at the facts. Yesterday in this chamber, when I asked Senator Evans, the Minister for Resources and Energy, what was happening to oil exports, he clearly cast doubts, in fact cast substantial doubt, on the future for oil exports from Australia. He said at one stage that export shipments had been maintained at a reasonable level `up, I think, until just about right now'. In other words, from now on they are not reasonable. He conceded that it was certainly questionable whether they would continue at the same volume and at anything like the same price that they have been recently.

The significance of Senator Evans's admission is this: In the first seven months of this financial year oil exports rose by 60 per cent to $1.8 billion. That has never been achieved in the past. It is far beyond anyone's expectations of what would happen to Australian oil. In fact, it is incredible that at the time of these generally fairly depressed world prices for oil Australia should convert from being a net importer to being a net exporter. I certainly hope that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), who represents the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) in this House, would address his mind to this question: If these oil exports are now to fall, what other exports will take their place in order to protect the Australian balance of payments from further disaster? He was asked this question late last year when he, like other Government Ministers, professed that there was no real problem about this sort of thing, that everything was on track and that the country was in the very best of hands. It reminds me of the musical Li'l Abner where Jubilation T. Cornpone had great success in losing every battle that he entered.

On the economic front this Government is now facing a continual succession of major defeats. It changes every target immediately it recognises that it cannot meet it and we have this incredible balance of payments situation where, for the first time in our history, there is a $500m credit our way in oil. Who would have thought that Australia would have become a net oil exporter rather than a net importer? There has been a $700m turnaround from the same period last year. Now we see, from Senator Evans's reply in this chamber, that this is all temporary, that it is most unlikely to last, and that there are question marks over even existing approvals for oil exports. In fact he says-and I repeat this absolutely vital phrase-`It is a matter of conjecture whether oil exports will continue at the same volume and at anything like the same price'. So what is going to happen for the rest of this financial year to our current account and the balance of payments? Oil is the biggest single factor, the biggest single element, holding up the balance of payments to this level. Let us face it, this level is disastrous. It is a deficit of $8.4 billion for the first seven months of this year, a record deficit. There has never been anything like it.

This situation would have been so much worse had it not been for the temporary stimulus given by oil, and that temporary stimulus will simply not be there for the remaining five months of this year if Senator Evans's doubts are translated into reality. Let us also look at the Russian wheat order-a once-off stimulus to the current account. For the month of December Australian wheat exports suddenly jumped from $300m to $501m. When that Russian wheat order finishes, what is going to happen to our wheat exports? In the American and European Community situations we see agricultural commodities being dumped around the world, dumped into our markets, yet the Government is still pretending to the people of Australia that its deficit on current account will blow out to only about $11.25 billion. That is bunkum. We know that it is bunkum because the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which is, as I understand it, the major source of input to the Government on this matter, according to media leaks has already advised the Government that the deficit will blow out to over $12 billion. That is something like $2 billion worse than the budget forecast made last year.

These matters have enormous significance to what happens to every Australian. Normally when Australians look at the headlines and see that there are balance of payments problems and so on, they say: `Okay, but how does that affect me?' The simple reality of how it affects them can be seen from this week's news, on many fronts. Apart from the reduction in the amount of money available for housing, the clear implications for inflation of any weakening in the dollar and so on, the hard truth, and the most significant and direct impact on Australians of the Government's mismanagement of the economy, is the increase in the interest rate on personal loans from at least one major bank which will extend into others.

What does the increase in the interest rate on personal loans mean? It means this: More and more of Australian consumer borrowing is done by way of personal loan. That is really where ordinary Australians feel the pinch. For example, when I recently bought a car I had to finance it, in part, by a personal loan. When many Australians seek to buy a house or build an extension on their house they cannot get the money from the savings banks because the Government has put such a ceiling on savings bank interest rates that no one lends to savings banks any more. So savings banks cannot lend to people. So they get it by personal loan. Personal loans from the banks are, if you like, the front line of action in the Government's economic mismanagement. That is where the people feel the pinch. This Government has created a situation whereby interest rates will inevitably continue to be high and continue to hit ordinary Australians unfairly and unreasonably. While that policy continues I believe the Australian economy will be subject to remarkable and unfortunate pressures. All I ask, basically, is that the Government come clean now on what its real targets in all these areas really are. For too long we have heard bunkum. I hope that the Government starts to come clean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proud to be following my colleague Senator Michael Baume's remarks about the economy because one or two points which he mentioned deserve amplification and, in fact, reiteration. Let us start, first of all, with the situation regarding the balance of payments in this country. He has rightly drawn our attention to the fact that the Government's objective now of $11.25 billion is going to be extraordinarily difficult for it to reach. In fact, he has quite clearly pointed out that the balance of payments deficit this year may well be in excess of $13 billion. That being so, we can expect only more of the same in terms of higher and higher interest rates in this country while that situation continues.

SPEECH.PARA: The amazing thing about this Government's policy in regard to our balance of payments is that everything that has been done is merely an attempt to smooth over the immediate problem, because the Government knows that at the core of the economic difficulty with the balance of payments is the trade union movement and its push for higher and higher wages and, of course, extra benefits such as superannuation for employees. Those things are being aided and abetted by this Government through its positive determination that superannuation is indeed a good thing for the community at a time when we in this country face incredible difficulties.

It is amazing that the Government has not taken a more gradualist approach to the productivity case before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, indeed, sought a more reasonable implementation of a program such as it has in mind. But no, we have a broad, sweeping approach to superannuation of ensuring that every industry, irrespective of its capacity to pay, will have costs imposed upon it at a time when it is least able to meet those costs. This, of course follows a very difficult situation with interest rates. One only has to look at the condition of our rural industries to appreciate the difficulties that the great exporters of this country are facing at this very time. We have the highest interest rates in real terms for 50 years in this country, yet the Government persists in maintaining those rates at very high levels through a deliberate policy to ensure that it keeps some control of the money supply.

As Senator Michael Baume has pointed out, the interest rates structure is continuing to rise day to day. Banks and financial institutions are being forced to raise interest rates on Bankcard and on personal loans as a direct result of the Government's policy. TALK.START.PARA: —And personal abuse in the House.

—And, of course, adopts personal abuse of the Opposition for drawing attention to that particular matter. If that is the standard by which this Government continues to run the affairs of the nation, we have very little hope for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect to the balance of payments, however-and I would like to return to that point-my attention was drawn recently to a very impressive analysis done by Mr Terry McCrann in the Age of 7 February 1986, where he compared the trade balances of Canada and Australia. I think it makes very informative reading for all of us in Australia at present. Just to take the latest available figures for 1985, the trade balance measured in United States currency for Canada reveals a surplus of some $US14,000m, whereas Australia's position is a negative of $US500m. In terms of the current account, which is the vital figure that we are looking at, the latest available figure, for 1985, shows that in Canada there was in fact a balance between exports and imports, while in Australia there was a deficit of some $US7,500m. We are used to figures of a higher dimension than that because we measure our balance of payments in terms of Australian dollars, which, of course, accounts for the fact that the figure for 1985, in our terms, is something like $11,000m. The point I would like to make here is that at the time these figures are up for analysis, which is February 1986, there is a parity between the Canadian dollar and the Australian dollar in terms of United States currency. In other words, a Canadian dollar will buy as much in the United States as will the Australian dollar. The point is that our current account is in deficit to the tune of $US7.5 billion while the Canadian current account is in fact in balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the essential difference.
—This is the essential difference, the essential point. I think we have to alert ourselves to make sure that we properly understand the implications of that.
—Does the Government?

—Of course, it does not because it is, as he says, whistling in the dark and hoping that everything will be all right, whereas it is quite clear that disaster lies immediately ahead of us. The international markets are measuring our currency temporarily as being in parity with that of Canada, which is in a far stronger balance of payments situation than is this country. Where is the remedial action being taken by the Government to ensure that that position is reversed? We do not see it. We certainly have no appreciation of the underlying fundamental reasons for the difficulty with our balance of payments, which, of course, relate to our lack of competitiveness in the international market-place. Rather, the Government continues to whistle in the dark and to feed the trade unions with support in the Arbitration Commission when it knows darn well that it has to face up to the problems of very high labour costs in this country which are affecting our balance of payments overseas and, consequently, the lack of confidence in the Australian economy which is causing the difficulties that we see in the statistics that we are reading.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be acknowledged that there is a very dangerous period ahead for the Australian economy. The Government talks about three years of growth, but they have been funded by overseas borrowings which have doubled in Australian terms over the last three years. Both private and public borrowings have risen from some $30 billion to over $60 billion. Obviously that means that there are difficult roads ahead for all of us.

Let us just turn to the Budget deficit and, indeed, the problems with the economy, which again Senator Michael Baume touched on. It is clear that the Government has many dilemmas in this area. It has the problem of what it will do with fuel prices. It is already planning to break promises by not adopting the import parity price system to its full and allowing the benefits of the lower price for oil to flow on to Australian consumers. It is, of course, faced with very significant changes in its expenditure patterns. We are already seeing overruns in the 1985-86 Budget in many different departments. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise today a matter which comes into the responsibility of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) in his new role as Minister representing education in the Australian Capital Territory. I am pleased that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who represents him in this chamber, is present and can perhaps convey my remarks to the Minister, who, I hope, will comment upon them and make a statement at some time. There are two parts to it in a sense, though they both relate to the provision of primary schooling in the Territory. Specifically I want to talk about the McKellar primary school. More generally, I ask: What is the Government's policy now for providing primary education in the future?

SPEECH.PARA: The documents which have been obtained under the Freedom of Information Act are some one inch thick. I shall not go through them all; I shall merely canvass some of the important issues that cover the history of the as yet non-existent McKellar primary school. On 11 August 1983 the National Capital Development Commission advised the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority that the construction of the suburb of McKellar had reached such a stage that it should urgently advise of its needs for the construction of the primary school so that it would be open when it was perceived to be needed in the first term of 1986. Let met just say that it has not opened and it has not been built. On 19 September 1983 at a Schools Authority meeting it was stated that McKellar primary school students could be bussed to other schools and that the construction of the school could be avoided by the long term use of transportable buildings at the Evatt and MilesFranklin primary schools.

The construction of primary schools in the Australian Capital Territory has always been on a neighbourhood basis. A primary school is roughly at the centre of a suburb and the roads and paths feed into the primary school. There is a fairly extensive system of roads around the suburb which young children do not have to cross. So to go to a primary school out of area inevitably means crossing a fairly major road. That is the way the place has been built. At the same time, nobody is denying that primary schools in the older suburbs have lost numbers. Some have closed; many of them have sections of their buildings no longer being used. So the need for perhaps a review of policy is understood.

On 26 October 1983 the Schools Authority advised the NCDC that McKellar primary school students were to be accommodated at Evatt, Miles Franklin and Giralang. That, of course, caused some considerable response. I shall not go through all the things that occurred from then until March 1984 when the Schools Authority reversed its decision and decided to build the primary school for a number of reasons, including of course the geographic situation that I referred to and the number of students likely to be there. The Schools Authority then put out a Press release saying that the school would be built and was to be available first term of 1986. The NCDC was advised.

It was on this basis that most of the land in this suburb of McKellar was sold. The prices for the land in the suburb of McKellar were significantly higher than they might have been-significantly higher than expected. People rather prized the fact that they would be able to build in a nice suburb, in a good setting near a primary school. At a meeting I attended quite recently of several hundred McKellar residents, it was very clear indeed that these people had bought their land knowing that the school was to be built there. It was part of the instructions in relation to the sale of the land, the advertising campaign, that the school would be there. The auction document said, in part:
It is intended that a primary school will be opened in McKellar in 1986. Until this facility is available, McKellar students may enrol at Evatt Primary School.

In October of last year the Schools Authority took a decision not to build the primary school. Whether the reason is that the Government has not provided adequate funds for capital development, or what the financial difficulties are, is not necessarily clear. No one doubts, of course, that there are financial difficulties faced by the Government. The two previous speakers this afternoon have dealt with that in some detail, and certainly that is an aspect that would need to be considered. But we are talking about the very important issue of educating our young children and their welfare and their well-being.

Somehow, the Schools Authority, having made a decision in early October not to build the school, kept it to itself. It apparently conveyed the decision to the NCDC, but it was not until later in October that it became known, or leaked out I guess, that the school may not go ahead. One of the residents there wrote a letter, a copy of which was sent to me. I could scarcely believe it after the earlier history as to whether it would or would not be built. I asked a question of the then Minister on 8 November. It is, of course, an area that is also in her electorate. She did not know that there had been any change and said:
I am not aware of any change in the schedule for the development of schools in new areas . . .

Subsequently the same afternoon she informed the Senate that a Schools Authority meeting had decided not to build the McKellar primary school. Since then, of course, there has been a fair amount of activity in the suburb, including the meeting that I referred to which was extremely well attended. The major reason was the relatively small size of the suburb of McKellar. It is the same size as Aranda; Hawker is smaller; and Cook is larger. McKellar really is average. Perhaps that goes to the other point that I was making as to the size of neighbourhood that should be provided with a primary school.

One of the other reasons was that there are first-class education facilities nearby. Nobody is going to suggest that the facilities at Evatt, Miles Franklin and Giralang are not first-class, but perhaps it is the `nearby' that is the matter for concern. The suburb has 953 homes, 3,250 residents, and a projected primary school enrolment of 440. As I say, I shall not go through every issue in this regard; I will just refer to some of them.
The School Authority's own impact statement reveals some interesting information. I shall briefly touch on some of the points on pages 4 and 12: One point made was:
It is not expected that provision of a school at McKellar will accelerate the decline of the three nearby schools.
Another point was:
Physical planning in the region has not specifically allowed for large numbers of primary aged children travelling from McKellar to other suburbs.

That is significant. The NCDC has expressed concerns about the decision not to build because it would be against the neighbourhood concept. It anticipated considerable public criticism. Of course it was right about that. It was very concerned about the safety of children being required to travel to other suburbs. The report referred to the information available to private land purchasers prior to this decision, that is, the number of people there who expected the school to be built, and so on. The impact study report goes on for many pages. It is difficult to know how the Authority came to the decision it did, in the light of the information in that report. The question is: Why are the people ofMcKellar being treated differently from those in the rest of the Australian Capital Territory?

As to the future, it may well be that the time has come to reconsider how our schools are constructed and whether or not the neighbourhood areas should be much larger so that a primary school may be much larger in the beginning with a certain number of demountable buildings as part of its natural construction initially which will settle down to a size for the future.

As honourable senators would know, the NCDC is presently planning the extension into the area known as Gungahlin. Hopefully, this question will be getting close attention for the new development. It seems a little harsh, to say the very least, if not unfair to the people who have purchased land there, to suddenly change the rules at this stage. I think it needs to be re-examined. I am concerned about the safety of the children in McKellar travelling to the other three primary schools that I have mentioned. There are busy roads in that area that would have to be crossed.

If children are being bussed, that raises another issue as well. The nature of the suburb is such that roads lead into the primary school site. The primary school, with its parents association and its school board, is the focus of life in a suburb of Canberra and it would be a pity if that were broken. I think we need an explanation as to what happened to the McKellar primary school. We also need a statement as to the future policy on the construction of schools, particularly in the primary area.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I remind the Minister that on 29 November last year in the Senate I asked him a question about a detailed survey being undertaken by the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries to determine the effects of the proposed fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle industry. I further remind the Minister that he told the Senate at that time that the Government's conclusions about the proposed fringe benefits regime were based on sets of quite conflicting information and he made it clear that he welcomed the survey and would take steps in light of the survey when it came to hand. I now ask the Minister: Has the Government received a detailed assessment by the Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries on the impact of the proposed fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle industry? If it has, does this survey confirm earlier forecasts of a severe reduction in vehicle sales, especially Australian made vehicles, if the tax comes into force? Will the Government now agree either to abandon the fringe benefits tax or at least to modify its application to avoid serious disruption to the car industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the previous question asked of me by Senator Chaney in relation to this matter. It is true that at that time the FCAI was in the course of preparing a survey and analysis of the effects of the fringe benefits tax on the motor vehicle industry. That assessment is now in the hands of the Government and it is being examined. It is a fairly detailed assessment. It is fair to say that the assessment of the FCAI predicts a substantial downturn in vehicle sales as a result of the fringe benefits tax and argues that in the course of the analysis which follows the survey. I want to point to a number of other factors which I believe the Government has to take into account in assessing the survey and the conclusions which it draws. The first factor is that for the last two years vehicle production in Australia has been at all time record levels. It was likely that there would be some decline in the production and sale of vehicles in Australia in 1986.
—Why? The population is going up.

—I suppose the most likely reason for it to happen would be the possibility of a government such as Senator Sheil's government being elected, because the industry was never at record production levels in that period. In fact, it suffered a very severe downturn at the end of that period of government. There are all sorts of discussions and projections about the capacity to sustain the very high levels of growth in the economy to the extent to which they were sustained in 1983 and 1984. For Senator Sheil's benefit, if he has not wafted off completely, that is a relevant factor in determining the number of vehicles which will be produced and sold in Australia in 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to complaining-I use the word `complaining' not in any pejorative sense-about the fringe benefits tax, the industry has also expressed concern about the effects the unleaded petrol conversions will have on motor vehicle sales. That regime commenced as from 1 January 1986. The industry has also expressed concern about the sales tax regime and the alterations which have been made to that regime. I think that any effects of the fringe benefits tax have to be seen in the context of other factors which may well affect volumes in the motor vehicle industry this year.

Having said all that, I shall answer the third part of the question, which was: Will the Government abandon the fringe benefits tax on cars? The answer to that question is no. The reason the answer to that question is no is fully illustrated by reference to the White Paper on taxation. The fact of the matter is that, in respect of fringe governments, the Government was losing-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying you have got a fringe government?

—We would have a fringe government if the honourable senator was anywhere near these benches. If I might say so, it would be a lunatic fringe government if the honourable senator was anywhere near these benches. We will not abandon the fringe benefits tax in respect of motor vehicles. I was saying that the reason for that can be found in the tax White Paper; that is, the enormous loss of revenue to the Government in respect of fringe benefit payments instead of salary. I think that the figure which the tax White Paper put on it was $700m and that figure was expanding at a very rapid rate. Certainly, the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles will not be abandoned. Whether it may be modified will depend on the assessment made of the FCAI paper and discussions which are currently taking place about that paper.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his very full reply, but there was one point which he omitted in that very full reply and that was the reference to whether the survey suggests that the reduction in motor vehicle sales will arise especially in Australian made vehicles-I think that is an important element of it-or whether the reduction which is predicted will apply across the board.

—I think I can best answer that question by saying that my recollection of the survey is that the estimated effect is across the board, but the survey also deals with the question of what is called down-sizing, which means that instead of having a Ford Falcon or a Commodore people might well buy a four-cylinder car.
—What, an imported four- cylinder car at an enormous price?

—As Senator Lewis points out, either an imported four-cylinder car at an enormous price as a result of the devaluation or a locally manufactured four-cylinder car. In answering that question I do not wish to qualify the answer in any way, except that I would point out that other sectors of the industry would probably have a different view about that.
