—My question without notice is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 11 February, in answer to a question of mine, the Minister stated that the United States strategy of destroying Soviet nuclear missile submarines at the outset of conventional war would increase the risk of nuclear war and was of questionable wisdom, but that this strategy was only one option. What is the Government's official position now that Casper Weinberger, the United States Secretary of Defence, in testimony to the US Senate Armed Services Committee on 10 February, has confirmed that this is not an option but the strategy to be pursued by the United States? How can the Government explain that something as vital as this, which involves North West Cape giving instructions to destroy Soviet submarines, was not known to it? Does it not again prove that the Australian Government has no input into developments in United States strategy which affect us and that it learns of most of these developments from newspaper reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that since my answer on 11 February, Secretary Weinberger and Admiral Crowe, the United States Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have been reported to have acknowledged that conventional attacks on nuclear missile submarines, outlined by Admiral Watkins in his maritime strategy article, are among the options available to the United States in the event of war. I do not accept Senator Sanders's characterisation of the Watkins proposal as amounting to the strategy. The United States maritime strategy is not a detailed war plan; it is, as we understand it, a framework for considering all possible uses of maritime power in a broad range of strategic contingencies ranging from peace to full-scale war.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be made clear that what we are talking about are attacks by conventionally armed nuclear hunter killer submarines against Soviet nuclear missile carrying submarines. However, as is acknowledged by Admiral Watkins in his article, were this tactic to be actually employed in a crisis, of firing conventional weapons against nuclear missile carrying submarines, it could pose serious dangers of escalation. Obviously the United States Government is as well aware of that as the honourable senator and, indeed, the Australian Government.

I repeat that the doctrine does not constitute any dramatic new direction in United States thinking. We have long believed that both the super powers target their attack submarines against opposing ballistic missile submarines. Indeed, that is one of the primary functions for which nuclear-powered attack submarines are designed. More generally, it has always been the case since nuclear weapons were developed that an opponent's nuclear weapons would be the primary targets in any nuclear exchange. Both sides of the super power confrontation have long recognised that sea and airborne nuclear weapons have a very high chance of surviving a counter force strike. Hence the prospects of either side being confident of its capability to mount a successful first strike are, as I said on 11 February, extremely remote and indeed neither is likely to achieve that capability.

I should add-as perhaps I should have done but did not on 11 February-that not only is the acquisition of a fully effective first strike capability by either super power not, as we see it, a realistic possibility, but it is also the case that the Australian Government does not accept the characterisation of United States strategic policy in terms of first strike or nuclear war fighting. We take very seriously the statements that have been made by United States leaders, including President Reagan and Defense Secretary Weinberger, in their repeated emphasis that the United States strategy is purely defensive and that a pre-emptive or first strike by the United States has been ruled out.

Finally-and I believe this is the most relevant point to this continuing debate, and it is a point that I made strongly on 11 February-there is the role of the North West Cape in the implementation of any such strategy. The Australian Government does not acknowledge that North West Cape need play any role in the strategy which Admiral Watkins canvasses in this article. Were that strategy to be followed, the participation of North West Cape would depend entirely on where Soviet ballistic missile submarines were deployed. In view of what we know of Soviet submarine doctrine, those submarines are extremely unlikely to be in our region. I am advised that it is the belief of the Australian Government that no Soviet ballistic missile submarines are deployed anywhere in the Indian Ocean or, for that matter, in the mid or South Pacific Ocean.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister deny that the Watkins policy was in fact confirmed by Mr Weinberger, or is he simply aware of the Weinberger statement?
—I am aware of the reported statements of Mr Weinberger and I believe their appropriate characterisation is in the terms that I have already advanced.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The Minister will be aware of a very unfortunate accident which occurred on 16 January 1986 between an Australian National goods train and a semi-trailer at a level crossing at South Burnie, Tasmania. The smash resulted in the deaths of three people-the goods train driver and his assistant and the semi-trailer driver. Will the Minister inform the Senate of developments in relation to the setting up of an inquiry into the accident?

—The Government is aware of the tragic accident that took place at a level crossing at South Burnie about five weeks ago involving the loss of three lives. The crossing is protected by flashing lights which the Minister for Transport advises me were operating at that particular time, according to independent witnesses. Australian National has the responsibility for the rail line in Tasmania. In 1985 the Tasmanian Level Crossing Warning Committee completed a study of level crossing safety including at South Burnie. At that particular time it did not find any deficiency in respect of the equipment operating there. Having regard to the evidence of the witnesses to the accident it does not appear that there was any default in respect of the operation of the equipment. Australian National has established an internal inquiry into that accident. Following its report in the near future the Minister for Transport will consider whether there should be an independent inquiry.

—Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of an agreement between the Tasmanian and Federal governments in relation to woodchipping in Tasmania? Is it a fact that the agreement has been signed by Tasmania's Premier but not by Mr Kerin? Is it a fact that the powers of the Federal Government in regard to State industries covers export operations and not domestic operations? Is it a fact that the reason the Government has not signed the agreement is that at the recent State election some of the massive loss suffered by the Labor Party was picked up not only by the Liberal Party but also by the conservationists and that this procrastination is an effort to kowtow to the conservationists? Finally, can the Minister indicate when the Government will sign the agreement?

—I do not know why Senator Walters is asking me this question. It might more appropriately have been addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. However, let us assume that the agreement which follows from a decision of the Government after lengthy consultations with the Tasmanian Government has not been signed at this stage. Therefore, the answer to Senator Walters's question is, first of all, yes, it is true that in respect of this industry the national Government has powers, and only powers, in respect of exports. That is true. The matters of domestic policy predominantly are in the hands of the Tasmanian Government. Nonetheless, I believe it is incumbent on any national Government to consider the circumstances in which exports are made from this country. That is quite an appropriate exercise of national government power, and has always been so regarded. That is the essence of or basis for the Commonwealth's position on this matter. I do not know the reason why the agreement has not been signed however, I would assume that it is because of failure to reach conclusive agreement on some minor matters. I can assert that the reason why the agreement was not signed had nothing to do with the Tasmanian election.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. I understand that funds are available under the supported accommodation assistance program for a sexual assault support service in Tasmania. I ask: Has the Minister received any advice from the Tasmanian State Government about a recommendation on the project so that Commonwealth funds can be allocated for the establishment of this centre? There is no rape crisis centre in southern Tasmania and I believe this is a matter of great urgency. Has the Minister taken any steps to move the process along so that the matter can reach a satisfactory conclusion at the earliest date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Funds are available under the supported accommodation assistance program for the establishment of a rape crisis or sexual assault support centre. The fact that such funds are available has been agreed to by both the Federal and State governments. Last year the Federal and State governments asked for people to apply for funds and to put up suggested projects under this scheme. Indeed, early in the year two organisations applied. The Commonwealth-State committee established by the Federal Government and the State Government considered the applications and, indeed, came down with a recommendation. What happened next was that there were two further extremely late applications. The State Minister asked the committee to reconsider the applications in the light of the two further applications. The Committee did so and, once again, made a certain recommendation to the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: Minister Cleary, who is no longer a member of the Tasmanian Parliament nor, of course, a Minister, apparently was again reluctant to accept the recommendation of the committee. He put to me that he wanted further time to consider it. He wanted to establish a local committee. He wanted to get the groups together to see whether in fact some compromise could not be reached. I said that we could wait until the end of January to come up with a final decision. However, a decision cannot be made by either Minister unilaterally. It has to be made by both Ministers. I understand that the committee met and that no agreement was reached. Now that I know who the Minister concerned is in Tasmania I have been able to make contact with that Minister and have sent a telex to him asking him please to expedite his side of this process.

The matter concerns me from several points of view. Firstly, as Senator Giles said, there is no sexual assault support service in Hobart. Secondly, there has been a desire on behalf of women's groups in the community-from all parts of the philosophical, ideological and political spectrum, whatever one likes-to establish such a scheme. Propositions have been put forward by a broad-based group since 1983. I am disappointed that the Tasmanian Minister could not see his way clear to agree with the recommendations of the committee. I am disappointed-I must say I am somewhat suspicious-of the late submissions which came in, particularly as in the case of one group which submitted a submission it knew very well that the closing date for submissions was many months before its submission was put in. I am concerned that the decision which has to be made by the Tasmanian Minister should be made on the basis of what is best for the community and what is best for women in the community and not on the basis of any ideological hang-ups people have down there.

Therefore, as I have said, I have asked the new Minister to look at what has happened in order to expedite the decision making process. I do not believe there is any reason for further delay. I do not believe that probably there is any reason for further ignoring the decisions of the committee which was established by both the State and Federal governments to look at this. The delay has come about because of the State Government's desire and the State Minister's desire, for whatever reason, to look again at the proposition. It has not come from the Federal Government. In fact, I am urging the State Government to get up, get along and make up its mind on what it believes so that we can look at the proposition, approve it quickly and get this much needed service off the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the strong recommendation contained in the 1984-85 annual report of the Family Law Council which proposes that section 44 (1b) inserted in the Family Law Act by the Parliament in 1983 be repealed. This section provides in effect that an application for dissolution of marriage may not be filed within two years of the marriage unless there is also filed a certificate stating that both parties have considered reconciliation with the assistance of a specified person or organisation. I ask: Firstly, is the Minister aware that this provision was introduced without any prior research or investigation; secondly, that marriage guidance organisations and counsellors of the Family Court have provided evidence overwhelmingly in favour of repeal; thirdly, that the two-year ban has been quite ineffective in promoting reconciliation, in fact that it is counter productive and is regarded by litigants as a tokenistic procedural restriction and a compulsory formality; fourthly, that it is demoralising to counsellors and wastes their much needed time? In view of the strong recommendation of the Family Law Council what action is the Government taking to repeal the provision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not correct to say that section 44 (1B) was inserted in the Family Law Act without prior research or investigation. It was inserted in the Act to implement a 1983 recommendation of the Family Law Council that former section 14 (6) of the Act be amended. That part of the Act, which section 44 (1B) replaced required both parties to a marriage of less than two years duration to consider reconciliation with a marriage counsellor prior to a hearing of a divorce application or to establish special circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: Experience showed that parties seldom considered reconciliation likely after divorce proceedings had commenced. The Family Law Council advised that it would be better if the requirements were to be met before proceedings were commenced. Section 44 (1B) gives effect to this recommendation. It provides the same bar to the hearing of divorce proceedings as did former section 14 (6), except that the requirements are to be met before divorce papers are filed. Section 44 (1B) has been the subject of further consideration by the Family Law Council, which has now recommended that it be repealed. It is true that the Council, in recommending its repeal, advances reasons along those lines that were mentioned by Senator Missen in his question.

I can say on behalf of the Attorney-General that consideration has been given to what action should be taken on the Family Law Council recommendation in the context of the general monitoring of the Family Law Act. This is one of the many matters that might be included in a family law amendment Bill when the Family Law Act is next to be amended. I say `might be included' because that has not been the subject of any decision at this stage. I will ask the Attorney-General to write to Senator Missen when he does decide what action should be taken to implement or otherwise this Family Law Council recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of recent comments of the head of the fraud division of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in Victoria which suggest that a number of Australian companies are now selling goods between one another in order to avoid tens of millions of dollars in sales tax? If so, what action is the Government taking to circumvent the rise of such activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of those statements, and the Treasurer is also aware of them. Comments along those lines appeared last weekend in the Good Weekend magazine, which is published as a supplement to a couple of the Fairfax newspapers, in an article entitled: `A crime we all paid for'. I understand also that the statement was made with a view to highlighting the fact that the Office of the DPP was also active in other areas of sales tax avoidance. The Commissioner of Taxation has told the Treasurer that sales tax evasion through the use of cash transactions and fraudulent practices has also put revenue at risk. Accordingly, the investigation of those practices has been afforded the highest priority.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of increased investigation activities, a number of cases suitable for prosecution under taxation laws or the Crimes Act have been uncovered. Of these, one has been successfully prosecuted and 11 others have been referred to the DPP. Another 20 of the more serious cases have been referred to the Australian Federal Police for further investigation. Of course, as Senator Bolkus probably remembers, the Government, for its part, enacted amendments to the sales tax laws in May of last year, which were designed to counter evasion by strengthening both the sales registration and quotation procedures and also the Commissioner's power of access to goods. From memory, I think it was estimated that those two pieces of legislation will affect the revenue by something between $300m and $400m a year, which shows that once the cancer of tax evasion originating in the income tax area spread from the West Australian Liberal Party's finance committee to the rest of the country, it also spread into the area of sales tax. This Government is making repeated efforts to stamp it out despite the continued frustration through the Senate not allowing the Government to do it effectively.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

—I ask the honourable senator to tell us under what company names he hid his Poseidon share transactions back in 1970.

It is true that 15 years ago and, indeed, as recently as four years ago, the Queensland economy was growing at quite a rapid rate because Queensland happened to be endowed with many natural resources, particularly coal, which were in demand or were thought to be in demand at that time. Since that bonanza disappeared and the resources boom mirage went off the horizon, the Queensland economy has been in dire trouble because the Bjelke-Petersen Government has no strategy for coping with it. ANSWER.PARA: Queensland finished the year with record bankruptcies, a dramatic increase in industrial disputes, and with unemployment rising against the national trend and the highest of mainland States.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the damage it has done to the coal industry with those rail charges?
—Similar cross subsidies or hidden taxes are extracted from Queensland coal producers.
—Senator Walsh, I do not understand you. Who do you like?

—Senator Parer would be very well aware of the hidden taxes that the Queensland Government extracts from coal producers and other miners in order to provide other services to favoured constituents in different areas. If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to make a speech, I suggest he tells us the names of the companies through which he hid his share transactions in Poseidon back in 1969 and 1970 when he was getting inside information from his wife, who worked in Burrill and Jones's office.
—None of them were hidden in 1969. At least I am not a failed farmer who got thrown off the family farm.
—Order! I ask Senator Crichton-Browne to remain quiet.
—I apologise, Mr President.

—Finally, just on the question of employment in Queensland, the most recent figures-these are the raw figures-show that Queensland has the highest unemployment rate of any mainland State-a note exceeded only by Tasmania-and the national figure of 8.5 per cent is some 1.1 per cent below the 9.6 per cent figure in Queensland.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to comments made last week by Senator Kilgariff supporting the provision of Commonwealth funds to construct a railway from Alice Springs to Darwin? Can the Minister say whether there are any grounds for Commonwealth funds to be provided for this purpose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was astonished to be told last Tuesday, 18 February, that Senator Kilgariff was not only arguing that the railway from Alice Springs to Darwin should be built, but also that he was endorsing the absurd proposition put forward by Katharine West that, if such a railway were built, ships with cargo destined for Sydney would unload at Darwin and the cargo would be sent by rail to Adelaide and then through Broken Hill to Sydney. Similarly, this would be the case in regard to cargo destined for Melbourne, and so on. Senator Kilgariff and I have had our differences about a few things but I always thought he was a man with some basic common sense. I must say I am astounded to find that he is endorsing this West proposition, this piece of arrant nonsense, that, if such a railway were built, cargo would be discharged at the port of Darwin and sent by rail to the rest of Australia. He will be giving testimonials for snake oil next.

ANSWER.PARA: The railway proposition is riddled with newspeak. The present Chief Minister of the Northern Territory uses these terms:
When I say private, I mean that it will be privately designed, constructed, financed, owned and operated.

Of course, it comes out a bit later, when one digs a little deeper, that this proposition for a private railway, which it is said will be economic, is neither private nor economic. It is not private because hidden away in the wish list is a desire or intention to extract free capital from the Commonwealth Government for its construction. It is not entirely clear whether the Northern Territory is looking for 100 per cent of the capital or something less than 100 per cent. So it would not be privately financed. The intention, very clearly, is that it be financed very substantially, perhaps entirely, by the Commonwealth Budget. Of course, that capital is regarded as free. So a bogus calculation is made to determine whether or not the railway will pay its way, based on free capital from the Commonwealth Government. There are very few enterprises that cannot pay their way if they get free capital. The sort of thinking which is displayed in this proposition represents another dose of the economic cargo cultism which has overtaken the Northern Territory Government in recent years and which, for losses on the guarantees for the casinos and hotels alone, is likely to cost the territorial Budget $30m in each of the next two years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the Minister read a report in today's Australian Financial Review headed `Government oil policy is falling apart, say refiners'? Has the Government considered a new policy on crude oil pricing to prevent further long term damage, as claimed by the refinery industry? The industry states in this report that its potential inventory loss is now $600m and that, with the existing disparity between import parity pricing and international prices, companies would be better advised to close their refineries than continuing to purchase highly priced crude oil just to oblige the Government. What is the Government's latest position on compensation for the refineries? Further, is the Government soon to announce a new policy with regard to the oil industry?

—The Australian Financial Review article this morning seems to be based more on noises that the refining industry was making over the weekend and on Monday than noises it has been making subsequently. The truth of the matter is that I believe the refiners' stock problem, was undoubtedly a very real one, at least for the period at about the beginning of February, when they were obliged to continue buying oil at allocation prices rather than at cheaper prices available on the world market. But I also believe, as a result of discussions that have taken place over the last few days, that the problem has for all practical purposes been resolved. The terms of the resolution of that problem will be announced publicly at the same time as the Government makes its announcement early next week, I would expect, as to the rest of the oil market problem which, as honourable senators, and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in particular, would be well aware, has a number of inter-related dimensions. It was important to get some immediate understanding of how to solve the stock loss problem because of the program of liftings which the refiners had for the rest of this month and the need to get an understanding of their position before that program could be continued. TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1985 Senator Vallentine asked a question without notice concerning the Government's attitude to the Soviet Union's moratorium on nuclear testing and subsequently expanded that question to include Mr Gorbachev's latest package of arms control and disarmament proposals. I regret the delay, but I can now convey Mr Hayden's answer to Senator Vallentine. It is a long answer and it might suit the convenience of the Senate if I were to seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard, although I am happy to read it.

ANSWER.PARA: 2. On 29 July 1985 the Soviet Union announced that it would observe a moratorium on nuclear testing from 6 August 1985 to 1 January 1986 and indicated that the moratorium could be extended if the United States took similar action. On 15 January 1986, the Soviet Union announced that its moratorium would be extended to 31 March 1986.

3. Australia welcomes any interruption of the nuclear testing programs. However, Australia's pre-eminent objective in this field remains a mutually agreed comprehensive test ban treaty that would be legally binding, effectively verified and consequently durable. Australia does not regard moratoria as a substitute for the concrete steps that need to be taken to make possible the conclusion of the CTBT. Australia has and will continue to urge all countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, to be sufficiently flexible to allow work on those concrete steps or building blocks to get underway.

4. Also on 29 July 1985, President Reagan invited the Soviet Union to send nuclear experts to observe and monitor without pre-conditions a United States nuclear test at the Nevada test site. This was a unilateral variant of President Reagan's September 1984 proposal for reciprocal visits to nuclear test sites. More recently, President Reagan has proposed that United States and Soviet experts meet to discuss the problems surrounding the verification of limits on testing.

5. Australia views such proposals as facilitating the development of verification arrangements needed for a CTBT. In July 1985, a letter was sent to the Soviet Foreign Minister urging the Soviet Union to accept the offers made by President Reagan. The Government has continued to express these views to Soviet officials, including Mr Nazarkin, who visited Canberra in January, to discuss Secretary-General Gorbachev's recent proposals.

6. In addition to extending the moratorium on testing, Mr Gorbachev's 15 January proposals included a far-reaching plan for total nuclear disarmament by the year 2000. Mr Gorbachev also proposed the abolition of chemical weapons and certain measures in relation to conventional armaments. As I mentioned, a special envoy, Mr Yuri Nazarkin of the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Affairs, visited Australia recently to discuss Mr Gorbachev's proposals.

7. The Government sees a number of positive aspects in Mr Gorbachev's proposals: First and foremost amongst these is the complete elimination of nuclear weapons, an objective now endorsed by both superpowers and reaffirmed by Mr Gorbachev. This is, of course, also the objective of the Australian Government. The Soviet proposal recognises that this process will have to proceed in carefully worked out stages, subject to appropriate verification procedures, including on-site inspection, and is dependent on agreement being reached by all five nuclear weapon sites.

8. Some aspects of the proposals, however, are contentious and will need further clarification and amendment to take account of the security concerns of countries other than the Soviet Union. In short, a great deal of difficult and detailed negotiation lies ahead on the nuclear, chemical and conventional fronts if the objective of total nuclear disarmament is to be realised. The Government hopes that serious and substantive work in the major negotiating fora will commence without delay.

9. As to that section of Senator Vallentine's question relating to SDI, she will of course be aware that the Government does not endorse the United States SDI nor what it accepts to be a comparable Soviet research program.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Review of Defence Project Management

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the 243rd report of the Committee, on defence project management.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Report presents the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the Department of Defence's management of its major capital equipment acquisitions.

It is presented in two volumes. The first comprises the main report and contains the Committee's findings, recommendations and supporting arguments. The second volume contains analyses of sixteen current or recent Defence projects examined in detail by the Committee.
The Utz Report on the Higher Defence Organisation noted `a history of criticism and complaint surrounding Defence procurement'.
In an examination of ten major Defence projects, the Auditor-General found that `Defence project management practices were unsatisfactory, contributing to:
significant additional costs to the Commonwealth;
the need for scarce resources to be engaged in rectifying project problems; and
a diminution of the Defence capability through untimely delivery of equipment and facilities and through equipment and facilities not meeting technical performance objectives.'

The Committee sought to identify changes in Defence organisational arrangements, decision making processes and management systems which would improve the efficiency, effectiveness and accountability of Defence project management.

The inquiry encompassed the full range of activities associated with the acquisition of Defence equipment, from the conception of a need to the introduction of a specific brand item of equipment into service.

The Committee drew a great deal of its evidence from a detailed investigation of sixteen recent major Defence projects. The sample included some of Australia's largest peace time Defence equipment acquisitions.
I commend to Honourable Senators/Members the detailed assessments of these projects in Volume Two of the Report.
Of the sixteen projects examined by the Committee, eleven have failed or may fail to be completed on time, to budget or to technical requirements.
A multitude of factors have contributed to these unsatisfactory results. Most could be attributed to inefficient and ineffective Defence project management.
The most common shortcomings in Defence project management were:
inadequate evaluation of project proposals;
under-estimates of project costs, time scales and risks;
incomplete project planning;
inadequate evaluation of tenders;
contracts which did not specify all contract requirements or provide effective incentives for contractors to minimise cost or performance to schedule;
inadequate monitoring of contractor performance;
contract supervision which did not submit the (sometimes) large number of contract changes to sufficient scrutiny to preserve project budgets and schedules; and
generally slow Departmental decision making processes.
These project shortcomings reflected several systematic inadequacies in Defence project management:
a dispersal of project management responsibilities and authority;
inadequate project management resources, especially in numbers of staff and computer support;
a shortage of experience project managers;
limited training in project management at all levels;
low retention of knowledge due to a high staff turnover; and
inadequate management information systems within project offices and throughout the Department.
The Cargo Working Party

An illustration of the problems which can befall a project when insufficient and inadequate resources are applied to project management is provided by the design of the cargo handling and storage systems on the Navy's new fleet underway replenishment ship, HMAS Success.

A Cargo Working Party was formed in February 1977 to address cargo handling and storage on HMASSuccess. However, the Cargo Working Party did not meet for the first time until 3 months later in May 1977. There were long breaks in deliberations of the Cargo Working Party and in 1983 fundamental design parameters of the ship were still being addressed. The Committee was told that the reason for the lack of progress of the Cargo Working Party was its lack of resources until the middle of 1983.

Not only was the Cargo Working Party slow to produce results but sometimes the results themselves were wanting. A major decision of the Cargo Working Party was to retain the RAN standard pallet for ammunition and provision pallets on HMAS Success. There were sound reasons for this decision. Unfortunately, the Cargo Working Party did not think through the implications of the decision for the existing design of the ship.

The decision to adopt RAN standard pallet size for HMAS Success involved a difference of 600 kilograms in the weight of a single ammunition pallet. The heavier pallets needed a heavier forklift to carry them and the heavier forklifts required modifications to the ammunition lifts for carrying the forklifts down to the magazines where they move the pallets. The combination of heavier forklifts and pallets exceeded the concentrated load designed for the replenishment deck and the deck has to be strengthened. Existing stowage arrangements in the magazines were also deleted and a FORGEWELD system of flexible, adjustable stowage installed.
Perhaps fortuitously the Cargo Working Party decision cost only $150,000 and 10 weeks excusable delay.
Hiport/Medport

An example of the difficulties which can ensue the under-estimation of the complexity of a project and its associated risks is given by the history of the Army's Hiport/Medport Mobile Radio Terminals project.

The Department saw the project as a straight forward purchasing exercise although it involved significant design development for the initial equipment item. This failure to correctly estimate risk was a major contributing factor to two ensuing problems concerning the vetting of design drawings and the testing of initial equipment items.

The contract stipulated that design drawings would be submitted to the Commonwealth before initial equipment items were cleared for production. However, the Commonwealth under-estimated the number of drawings which were to be submitted by the contractor. Indeed, at the time of contract award there was no estimate of the number of drawings involved. The Army's Design Approval Authority was unable to cope with the number of contractor-supplied drawings and some 501 drawings were approved without vetting.

The contract also provided that prior to the manufacture of follow-on equipment, the initial production item was to be tested in accordance with contractor-supplied specifications to be approved by the Army's Design Authority. However, not only did the specification of the Commonwealth's test requirements in the contract omit the full series of tests but insufficient time was allowed under the contract for the approval of the contractor's test specifications.
The resolution of these problems resulted in an increase of $3.5m in project costs and a 41 months extension to the contract delivery dates.
The findings do not necessarily reflect Defence project management today. The Department has acknowledged and responded to many of the shortcomings identified by the Committee.

Over the five to six year time span of the projects under review there have been a number of improvements in Defence project management. Greater authority has been given to project directors and there has been a gradual increase in the level of resources allocated to project management.
In June 1984, after the inquiry was well underway, the major Defence equipment acquisition functions were centralised in a new Capital Procurement Organisation (CPO).
This change, Defence believed, would:
overcome the unsatisfactory dispersal of project responsibilities and authority;
assign more authority to project directors; and
simplify project organisational arrangements.
The effects of the re-organisation had yet to make themselves felt in the time frame of the Committee's inquiry.
The Committee believes the CPO initiative will significantly improve Defence project management. However, we have a number of reservations about the adequacy of these measures.

The change may represent only a formal change in the top management structure that will leave the underlying Service ways of doing things unchanged. The Committee believes that the procurement function should be given independence from the Services. In the past there has been a tendency for the Service sponsors or functional areas to maintain undue control, particularly over the technical aspects of projects. As a result large numbers of specification changes have been made with adverse effects on project costs and schedules.

Most project directors do not have authority commensurate with their enhanced responsibilities. In addition to their limited control over technical aspects, project directors have insufficient control over project administrative resources.
The measures make no explicit reference to training and other critical personnel management issues.
Current planning envisages only a limited and gradual upgrading of computer support for project management.
Basic Trainer Project

An example of the difficulties which can face a project when technical considerations are allowed to drive a project in seeming isolation from cost or schedule concerns is supplied by the RAAF's Basic Pilot Trainer Aircraft Project. In the Basic Trainer Project this situation arose out of the failure to resolve conflicting project objectives and divided project management responsibilities.

In addition to the acquisition of a suitable trainer aircraft, the RAAF wanted to re-establish a local military aircraft design capability to meet its overall aircraft support needs. The RAAF chose to pursue this objective by requiring the aircraft to be designed to military specifications. Another major objective of the project was the development of export sales to defray design and development costs and sustain the industry's acquired design capabilities. As aircraft design and development got under way however these parallel objectives of market- ability and the development of design expertise came into open conflict.

Dispute arose between the RAAF and the contractor (AAC) as to the status of the military specifications. AAC told the Committee that its understanding was that the specification was a target which would not be met to the full letter of the law. The AAC seemed prepared to compromise military specifications when 100 per cent compliance threatened to affect cost, schedule and the marketability of the design. The RAAF, the AAC argued, was insisting on strict compliance with the specification even when non-compliance would have no significant influence on the RAAF's aircraft performance requirements. The RAAF told the Committee that they were in a situation of designing an aeroplane to specification but not regardless of cost. They added however that `undue compromise of the specification . . . would contribute to defeating the purpose of the project'.

Under the management arrangements adopted for the Basic Trainer project, responsibility for the project was shared between the Air Force Materiel and Air Force Technical Services Divisions. Although the Chief of Air Force Materiel was responsible for the overall management of the project, the Chief of Air Force Technical Services was the Design Approval Authority and the Air Worthiness Authority. Parallel with Materiel Division's project management organisation, the Chief of Air Force Technical Services had personnel responsible for supervising the design, engineering and quality assurance aspects of the project although they were required to copy or channel relevant information through the Project Director or his representatives.

A thirteen month slippage in schedule and a prospective doubling of the project cost appears to have persuaded the Government to abandon local design and development and opt for the licensed production of an existing overseas design.
We believe there is considerable scope for further improvements in Defence project management.

Unfortunately, the Department of Defence appears not to share the urgency the Committee attaches to these improvements, largely we suspect, because it does not appreciate the full costs of inefficient and ineffective project management.
Failure to introduce Defence equipment on time, to budget or to technical requirements affects not only the Commonwealth Budget but also our Defence capability and Australian industry:
the savings forgone by projects not being delivered to cost represent resources not available to be applied to other Defence purposes or other areas of Government expenditure;
the shortfall in capability which may result from project delays is a cost to Defence preparedness; and

contracting delays and generally slow decision making processes impose significant costs on contractors and on the efficiency of Australian industry since Defence is a major customer of sections of Australian industry.

For the Committee, the apparently secondary priority Defence accords to efficient and effective project management underlined the importance of public accountability. If other Defence priorities outweigh efficient project management, then the choices and their consequences should be made explicit. Unfortunately, Parliamentary scrutiny of the Defence equipment acquisition process is inadequate.

The Committee has made sixty-eight recommendations to improve the effectiveness, efficiency and accountability of Defence project management; sixty-five for action by the Department of Defence and three for action by other Commonwealth agencies.
To improve the effectiveness of Defence project management the Committee has recommended:
(1) firmly delineating the responsibilities of the Capital Procurement Organisation and the Service sponsor or client organisation;
(2) assigning the Capital Procurement Organisation increased authority and control;
(3) delegating more authority to project directors, especially over technical and administrative aspects;
(4) increasing the level of staffing and computer support given to project offices;
(6) making greater use of project management expertise outside Defence, especially that in the private sector;
(7) implementing improvements in Defence project management information systems;
(8) improving the quality of Defence contracting and contract administration;

The further centralisation of procurement functions, the increased delegation of authority to project directors and increased computer support to project offices will improve also the efficiency of Defence project management by shortening decision chains and increasing productivity. The Committee believes there is considerable scope for further improving the efficiency of Defence project management by:
(9) modifying Departmental procurement approval procedures to
speed decision-making, and
improve the quality of information available to decision-makers
to allow a fuller consideration of cost-saving options, and
to avoid costly changes after contracts have been let;
(10) increasing the level of project management skills within Defence by
giving greater emphasis to project management experience in selecting key project personnel, and
expanding project management training at all levels;
(11) increasing the retention of project management skills by developing career paths in project management and related areas;
(12) consolidating Defence project management procedures and practices;
(13) providing stronger contractual incentives for suppliers to meet requirements on time and to cost; and
(14) reducing the potential for post-contract delays by simplifying procedures governing
design approvals,
contract changes, and
contract disputes.

The implementation of a number of these recommendations will require additional resources. Others will involve a reallocation of existing Defence resources. The Committee believes that improved efficiency will provide the necessary offsetting savings.

Improved accountability will be assisted by centralising functional responsibilities, establishing firm management performance baselines and improving management information systems. To provide the necessary external oversight the Committee has recommended annual reporting to Parliament on the major Defence equipment program.

The scope of the inquiry was very broad, touching upon all aspects of the Defence procurement cycle from requirement definition to in-service support. Some aspects, particularly in-service support, could not be covered satisfactorily within the time and resources available. During the inquiry the Committee received some evidence of shortcomings in spares procurement and equipment support. These are important matters and the Committee intends to address them in a follow-up inquiry.

A large number of people contributed to this Report. In the first place I would like to acknowledge the contributions of my colleagues on the Sectional Committee and also members of the Sectional Committee in the previous Parliament, Senator Georges, Mr Kent, Mr O'Keefe, Mr McGauran and Mr White.

We are grateful to the Department of Defence, the Department of Housing and Construction and other Commonwealth agencies for the co-operation and assistance extended during the inquiry. The Committee also thanks the members of its Secretariat, past and present, for their support.
The Committee looks forward to the response to this Report. We shall be monitoring the implementation of the recommendations with interest.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

Often times misstatements are made about the functions they perform. Often, attacks are made on the way in which they go about their task. However, in the end the Commission's function is to try to conciliate between people who have a dispute and to point out to government the ways in which legislation goes beyond what is considered as fair and reasonable. For that reason members of the Commission deserve our thanks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, will find it very difficult in five minutes to comment adequately on the annual general report of the Family Law Council. SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the Council points out that the number of complaints received by the court has decreased within the past 12 months. TALK.START.PARA: —They can't read their writing.

—I do not have time to go into that, but I can assure the honourable member that he is one hundred per cent right. The notes would mean a lot to the doctor but nothing at all to the members of the Family Law Court. Therefore, I show my great concern that the action by the Court is taken in this way and I ask the Minister to make some representation on behalf of the Senate to the Family Law Court to see whether this problem can be solved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with previous speakers that it is a nonsense we are expected to deal in five minutes with quite a massive and important report from the Family Law Council; I hope that there will be further discussions on it. Briefly, I will mention two or three things from the report. SPEECH.PARA: In addition there is a matter which has cropped up many times in the past and I do not mind repeating it: Attention has been drawn on page 30 of the report to the fact that referral of State powers in respect of children and property has never been attempted by the States. The Council is aware of the need to increase the level of contribution of liable parents but would be concerned if this objective were pursued at the expense of other social policy objectives including adequate levels of payment for children of sole parents and reducing the current disincentives for sole parents to seek paid employment.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Senator Missen:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The ninth report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which is before us, is a very good report. I think that we should congratulate the Authority and its Chairman, Graeme Kelleher, on the quality of the report and the information contained therein. I guess, as a Queenslander, it is fair to say that all Queenslanders look on the Great Barrier Reef as their very own. But then again, it must also be recognised that for very good reasons all Australians look on the Barrier Reef as their own. Thus, in 1975 an Act to establish the Authority was proclaimed. As one can imagine, that presented an opportunity for confrontation to take place between the Federal Government and the State Government. However, to the credit of everybody concerned, recognising the strong wills involved, a very good relationship has been set up. That does not mean that things go smoothly all the time and there is not a diversity of opinion. The way in which the Authority operates, with the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service being responsible for the day to day running, is working very well. I think that that is to the credit of the people involved in both the Authority itself and the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service.

SPEECH.PARA: As everyone would understand, the Great Barrier Reef is a vastly complex eco-system. It is not, as the name indicates, one reef. The very fact that there are passages through the outer barrier of the reef soon gives the lie to that. The outer barrier of the reef is made up of many reefs. Inside the Barrier Reef there are many more reefs, coral caves and so on. Its vastness is beyond most people's comprehension. The Chairman stated:

Because the Marine Park occupies an area which is larger than the combined areas of the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland, conservation of the Marine Park must always be carried out to a large extent by its users. Australia could not afford to manage the Park in the absence of public support.

That is very true. To survive, the Barrier Reef has to be understood first. It is there to be used, not abused. It is there to be enjoyed. Thus, one of the main roles of the Authority is that of an educative process. The Authority is doing that. It is putting kits together and going to the schools so that young people in particular can understand that it is not only our reef but also the reef for future generations of Australians. It is there to be enjoyed and used but certainly not to be abused. In other words, people have to try to understand it so that it can be protected.
I take issue with both Senator Sanders and Senator Missen in their comments the other day. Senator Missen referred to the fringing reefs near Cape Tribulation. He said:
It is a problem which concerns the people of Australia because it--
that is, the road-
has caused the destruction of some parts of the reef near the shore.

Senator Sanders reiterated that. I think, I could say, in the kindest terms, that that is not true. The very fact of building a road does not necessarily mean that there will be masses of silt and the destruction of the fringing reefs. There have been many roads built in north Queensland. There has been a road that has extended from the Daintree River to Cape Tribulation itself. One would surmise that if the siltation flowing down from the construction of the current road was going to cause great damage and the destruction of the fringing reefs it would have happened with the building of the road up to Cape Tribulation, but of course it has not.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of road is it? There are different types of roads.

—They all start the same. Firstly, the environment is disrupted by the use of bulldozers and so on. Having said that, I indicate that if anybody flying up and down the coast looks down there after any wet season or storm he will see the plume of the silt going out to sea. It is not as if this has occurred only since the white man came. What about the Burdekin River? There is a delta there which has been laid down over thousands of years, not the last 200 years, because of the silt coming down. The plumes are generally dissipated because of the north-south wash behind the reef. Some of the reefs are built in an area where a plume goes out and is dissipating. Those reefs, as have reefs in various other parts of the world, have learnt to adapt to the various circumstances in which they find themselves. The Authority has set up a monitoring program which will look at the reef near the Cape Tribulation road. The program will look at other fringing reefs near other roads which have been built and also at a reef which is nowhere near a road as a control section. I commend the Authority for doing that. I trust that we will learn something from it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Year after year the annual report of the Department of Transport perpetuates the nonsense that the Department is `concerned to encourage', or is `placing emphasis on', our coastal shipping being efficient, reliable and reasonably priced. The words `efficient, reliable and reasonably priced' have been in the Department's annual reports for years. The inclusion must be automatic. The words have never been heeded and they have never had any effect. Australia's coastal shipping is nothing short of a disaster area. It is subject to the Navigation Act, which effectively gives the Australian maritime unions a monopoly over coastal shipping and this monopoly has been ruthlessly exploited. All vessels engaging in the coastal trade must be licensed by the Department of Transport and vessels will only be licensed if manning standards are, to use the expression in this year's report, `adequate'. `Adequate' means complying with Australian safety, crewing and accommodation standards and Australian wage rates. A total of 104 vessels were so licensed in 1984-85.

SPEECH.PARA: The report says that three new Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd ships-two of 147,000 dead weight tonnes and one of 220,000 dead weight tonnes-will operate with crews of 26 each. Australian ships of this size currently operate with crews of 32, and the report correctly says that this represents an improvement of 19 per cent. But foreign crews for such ships are as low as 23 and-this is the crunch-we require two crews per ship per year, so that a crew of 52 will still be required for each ship in Australia, whereas foreign ships would require at a maximum a crew of 39 for each ship. In addition, foreign crews do many tasks which Australian crews, by award, do not do and which therefore have to be performed by shore dockyards, thereby increasing the unavailability time of a ship. This extra time and cost, plus the number of strikes by maritime unions, hardly makes the Australian coastal service `reliable' or `efficient'.

However, I welcome this first sign of a reduction in manning levels per ship. Manning levels alone are not enough however, and I suspect that costly concessions may have been granted to these crews as a reward for a reduction in crews to something closer to overseas levels. I have always insisted that a reduction in crew levels is useless if total crewing costs increase. What we must ensure is a reduction in the manning costs per ship. Annual and daily manpower costs of each Australian ship are at least double those of comparable Swedish or West German ships-ships from countries which have higher standards of living than we do. As an example of the unions' exploitation of their monopoly, BHP's shipping costs have been estimated to be at least $20m more per year than they would be if the company was using Swedish or West German ships. These extra crew costs greatly increase our transport costs, which then have to be borne by the Australian community, and reduce our international competitiveness, which of course is critical at a time when we are borrowing $1,000m a month to support our current standard of living. Inefficiency in transport is critical.

The Industries Assistance Commission found in its report on the fertiliser industry that shipping in an Australian ship adds about $20 per tonne to the price of phosphate and this extra cost, of course, is borne by the hard-pressed farmer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not, Senator; it is really borne by the manufacturer. I do not disagree with the point that you are making; I think the cost is horrendous.
—Well, it is borne by someone and it means higher production costs. In its draft report on chemicals and plastics, the IAC had this to say about the Australian coastal shipping industry:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has suggested in the past that the Government forward it a reference on coastal shipping to enable the regulation of coastal shipping to be closely examined with a view to identifying means by which cost imposts on Australian industry can be lessened.

Our coastal shipping, which should be the most economical method of transporting cargo between coastal centres, has been pricing itself out of business and that, coupled with our deplorable waterfront performance, has imposed very great extra costs on the whole Australian community for the benefit of a small number of militant and overpaid trade unionists. It is high time that we had a full inquiry into the whole present state and future needs of our coastal shipping trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Hamer is very experienced in the coastal shipping area and knows the maritime problems, it was very interesting to hear what he had to say. In speaking to the annual report of the Department of Transport for 1984-85, I must say first that this is a very comprehensive report and to speak on all its various facets would take some considerable time. Very briefly I wish to speak to the section relating to the railways. I spoke to the Australian National Railways Commission annual report a few weeks ago. That report indicated that the ANR was at least showing a profit, and from looking at that particular report I believe there has been a very substantial turn around. The railways were in the red but now they are a viable operation. That is extremely important and when one remembers that one can see that we are going through a very important period. With proper organisation, upgrading and such, the railways will be very viable in the future in Australia, which is a vast continent.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly interested to see that there has been consultation with railway unions. The Department of Transport report says:
Consultations with the rail unions continued during 1984-85 as an important part of the Government's strategy to improve understanding and co-operation within the rail industry.
This is very true, and it is extremely good to see that within the railway development there will be a Railway Industry Council. The report says:

Discussions at Ministerial level, through the Australian Transport Advisory Council, and with the rail unions on the major problems facing Australian railways resulted in an in-principle agreement to the establishment of a Railway Industry Council (RIC).

Rail authorities and unions will participate in this Council. I believe it is essential for the rail authorities and the railway union to come to some agreement and work together within this particular Council to plan the future of the railways. There can be no future for the extension or viability of the railways within Australia unless the railway unions come to an agreement and participate very strongly. The future of railways in Australia depends on the participation of the rail unions concerned. For too long we have seen disruption within the railway system caused by strikes by the unions concerned. I am pleased to see that at last there will be this co-ordination between authorities and unions to plan the future. Unions have a very important part to play in the development of the railways. The success and the viability of railways in the future will depend on the railway unions' participation. As I have said before, I believe there is a tremendous future for railways in Australia and the unions have a most important part to play in it.

I will not go on to the subject of the continuation of the north-south rail link. Construction has been completed from Tarcoola to Alice Springs, but the Alice Springs-Darwin link is still wanting. However, I will say that with the development of the railways now-the development to a viable state of affairs through the progressive attitude of the ANR-it will be of considerable importance that this rail link from north to south should be completed. All in all, when one looks at the progress that has been made within this area of the Department of Transport relating to the railways, one finds that it is very encouraging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of Transport annual report for 1984-85 is a good and well-structured report and the format is informative and imaginative. It is encouraging that the Department is tackling some of the less conventional aspects of road safety-for example, bicycle safety and helmets, driver education, better standards for commercial passenger vehicles, control of unsafe spare parts and accessories and also the difficult problem of safety on rural roads. It is to this area that I wish to direct the rest of my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The report mentions the rural crash study. This study was carried out by the Northern Territory Department of Transport and Works, the Queensland Department of Transport and the South Australian Department of Transport's Division of Road Safety. That study began last year and was announced in this report. The aim of the three studies is to determine which factors influence the frequency and distribution of crashes on rural roads and, in addition, to assess the relative importance of factors and interactions between factors. This is the most important study which we could make.

In our highly urbanised society most people live and drive in urbanised areas. Yet, more people die in Australia each year from road crashes in rural areas than die in urban areas. The Australian Democrats have been pressing for action on this issue for a long time. Last year during May and June the Hon. Ian Gilfillan, member of the Legislative Council in South Australia, conducted three phone-ins in South Australian rural areas on the subject of the country road toll. A large number of calls were received from a wide range of people of many different ages. The phone-ins identified a number of issues. The first was the lack of public transport in rural areas for those who drink and need to get home; the second was the poor skills of urban drivers in handling their cars on rural roads; the third was the dangers caused by heavy transports on these roads which sometimes are made out of gravel and whose surfaces are not as good as those of roads in the city; fourth was the presence of a large number of `black spots' and dangerous sections in rural roads. These have been drawn to the attention of those responsible for road maintenance in those areas. I hope that the Commonwealth Government will ensure that those `black spots' are handled and that the roads in those areas are repaired.

The lack of public transport as an alternative to drinking and driving in these country areas is a major concern. The distances which country people drive in order to socialise makes the problem of drink driving crucial and more difficult than in the city. Country social life often revolves around alcohol consumption at football clubs, cricket clubs or the local pub. Unlike city dwellers who have access to public transport or taxis when they are `under the weather', country people have little choice but to drive home. Even in major country towns people only rarely have any alternative to driving. This is one area that the rural crash study must consider.

Another area of concern which was revealed during the phone-ins was driving skills, especially for city people who rarely drive on rural roads. Rural roads are a totally different kind of road condition from urban roads. The speeds are greater, many roads have gravel shoulders, on which cars can skid, they are unlit at night and require completely different skills to those skills required for city driving. Drivers on rural roads require more sophisticated techniques which should be taught in city driving schools. For example, if a car hits the gravel shoulder, in order to prevent a skid the driver must not brake but drive carefully and unhastily out of the situation. The rural crash study must look into raising the skill levels of urban drivers to a level where they can cope with open road conditions. We must also make certain that heavy transports are looked after and that, as quickly as possible, the fast-track legislative package is introduced into the States so that the safety conditions for heavy transports and for other users of the roads can be improved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Transport and transport costs are at the very heart of our economic dilemma in Australia. Freight costs are the most central of all costs. Australia is in a dilemma. We have unemployment. We have an adverse balance of trade. We have an inability to service our debts because we are not cost productive in our international trade. In fact in Australia we cannot support competitive manufacturing industries.

SPEECH.PARA: A good rule of thumb in looking at transport costs runs this way: For primary industry 80 per cent of all costs incurred by farmers is incurred off-farm. They are outside the ability of the farmer to control. However, the second and fundamental issue is that, of all the costs of all commodities and services, something like 40 per cent are freight, in its broadest sense. Therefore, when one looks at the very heart of costs one sees that the very issue which ought to be engaging governments of Australia is that of freight.

The annual report of the Department of Transport is bland and, with respect, platitudinous. Today freight in Australia in all its forms-road, rail and sea-is scandalously ineffective and inefficient. When I was a young student at university sea transport was the cheapest of all movements of freight. It was cheaper by one-half the cost of rail or road. Today sea transport is uncompetitive. It is far too dear. Today in terms of overseas trade we are facing not only costs involved in moving freight-goods and commodities-to seaports from around Australia but also there are unnecessary immense extra costs in port handling. I mention the costs of handling grain and coal. I think the Japanese decided they would by pass Sydney for grain handling because of the delays, indeed, the inefficiencies in handling freight.

If I were to look at one major subject to which the Commonwealth ought to direct its attention at this moment I would look at a major study of freight and all its aspects in Australia. Indeed, if there is something central to Australia and something that can establish a co-partnership between the States and the Commonwealth and get them working together I suggest that this would be putting the elements of freight handling in Australia into a more efficient and rationalised system. I say this completely in a bipartisan way. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, is facing this as his central problem. As I said, 80 per cent of all farm costs are incurred off-farm. Forty per cent of all costs are freight. Therefore, let us get to the heart of this. Let us, as best we can, establish an inquiry. We are good at inquiries on lots of superficial things. Let us establish an inquiry to look at freight costs-to look into the very heart of our sea transport.

Senator Hamer, who has expert knowledge in this area, has pointed out the disabilities. What a tragic situation it is that Australia with its immense littoral-its immense coastlines-really cannot run its own Australian-manned shipping services. The Australian people themselves are good people when they understand the nature of the work and the job to be done. We ought to have a very large indigenous Australian shipping service. Because we look at conflict instead of consensus we are costing ourselves out of a job. We are destroying what could be a great contribution to getting costs down in Australia and to getting jobs for the Australian people. I rose to speak because I consider this subject of immense importance to the whole of the main task ahead of us in tackling the one central thing of the economy-how to make Australia more cost competitive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the annual report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission because it will be the last report that the Commission in its present form will present to this Parliament. Legislation is currently before this Parliament to change the name and the nature of the Commission. I speak as a former Minister who had the privilege of being responsible for the Atomic Energy Commission. Therefore it is timely to pay tribute-I think the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) who is present in the chamber will agree with me-to the work and services of those who have been responsible for the Commission in its present form.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has made one major transition when the former Government, under a rationalisation plan, separated the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The Commission managed that transition with great adaptability. I pay tribute in particular to the Chairman of the Commission, Professor Max Brennan, an eminent nuclear physicist who has brought to his task skill and dedication. I pay tribute to those who have served as deputy chairmen and members of the Commission, in particular Dr Walker, who carries the administrative tasks.

The Australian Atomic Energy Commission has indeed had a good record in Australia. There will be a change, not so much in the relevant Act or in the Commission's powers, because the legislation before us, apart from changing the Commission's name, will not alter to great effect its powers of research, but because the Government has foreshadowed that it is its policy to introduce legislation further to restrict this Commission. The Government has been making great noises about one aspect of this Commission that is to be a major feature in the future. I do not want to deprecate it. I refer to the production of radioactive isotopes. The fact is that these isotopes have played and are playing a significant part in industry, medicine and agriculture.

I want to put the situation in its true perspective. One does not need a nuclear research establishment to produce radioactive isotopes. The nature of the Commission is such that to overemphasise that this is the key focus of what the Commission needs is to make a false projection. In fact, it is quite possible to produce these isotopes in a commercial cyclotron in a commercial way. I am not saying that I am advocating that that should be done, but I am saying that in looking in the future at the work of the new Commission, the Senate and the community at large should not be beguiled into thinking that the Commission will be doing major work just by dwelling upon the use of isotopes. A commercial cyclotron is quite capable of producing them. What is important is that there should be available in Australia, through the universities and elsewhere, a facility for maintaining the peacetime knowledge of our students and future lecturers in the nuclear field. In a world that is growing more and more hungry for energy and because this present glut of oil is disguising the fact that we will run out of renewable fuel, one cannot tell when we will need to utilise the nuclear cycle for peacetime electricity generation. I rose primarily to pay tribute to those who have done excellent work, to those whom I have known and who have been involved in projects such as synroc, uranium enrichment and in other various fields. I wish those at the workface today every success for the future in their journey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the thirty-third annual report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. Like Senator Sir John Carrick, I too pay tribute to the Commission which has done tremendous work for Australia over the years. The present staff and the people who have served on the Australian Atomic Energy Commission are to be commended for what they have done for Australia. Today, I wish briefly to refer to that section of the report relating to the rehabilitation of overburdened heaps at Rum Jungle. Honourable senators will recall that Rum Jungle is some 60 miles from Darwin, near Batchelor. From 1954 to 1969, uranium was mined there by Consolidated Zinc Pty Ltd. There was a very savage deterioration of the environment. This was due to the mining and treatment operation and the disposal of waste products which was carried out within the strictures of the environmental regulations applying at that time. They were quite insufficient. It is important that we see just what poor mining operations can do to the country.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be stressed too that the pollution at Rum Jungle resulted mainly from the pyroetic nature of the overburden and from the ore treatment processes and that it was not directly related to the uranium mined. I believe that the Federal Government, the Northern Territory Government and those who were sub-contracted to work on the rehabilitation of Rum Jungle are to be very much commended. I refer particularly to a report on the rehabilitation of Rum Jungle produced by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. I commend the project engineer, Mr C. G. Allen, and his staff, who carried out this work for the Northern Territory Government, which was financed by the Federal Government.

Those who saw Rum Jungle in the first years were appalled by the death of the Finniss River. Plants and fishes died in the river; it was more or less dead. The water in Whites open-cut and Dysons open-cut was of extreme depth and so poisonous that no one could use it, not even as a sporting facility. The two governments have brought about the rehabilitation. I understand that a budget of some $20m was made available for this work. It is to the credit of all concerned that this work was carried out within the budget allocated some year ago. Even with depreciation, by making some savings in some areas, those involved were able to complete the work. I have been to Rum Jungle within the last few months and seen the rehabilitation project. Most of the work has been completed. It is something that most honourable senators should see if they are interested in such rehabilitation work. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
