Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Missen had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after `That', insert-

`debate on this Bill be deferred to enable consideration of the reference to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, or such other standing or select committee that is able to handle the inquiry, of the provisions of the Bill and other proposals already made or subsequently brought forward to provide a scheme for the effective assessment, collection and enforcement of maintenance payments (whether by order of a court, agreement or otherwise), so that both parents and spouses will pay adequate maintenance from their own resources before reliance is made on pensions or other payments by the Government'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has already been substantial debate on this measure and the Government's position has been well outlined in Senator Tate's contribution but it is, nonetheless, appropriate that I formally put on record the response of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Government to this private member's Bill, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1985. May I say at the outset that it is gratifying to see the concern for maintenance recipients which was expressed in Senator Durack's second reading speech but it is unfortunate in our view that the practical effect of the Bill will not satisfy the concerns which he identified.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deals with two broad issues: The effect of social security on the size of maintenance orders or agreements and enforcement by imprisonment. We see the Bill as being inadequate in both of those areas and, as a result, the Government opposes it. Let me explain in a little more detail why we oppose it. I will refer first to the social security aspect. Sub-clause 3 (1) of the Bill proposes to add two new sub-sections to section 75 of the Family Law Act. The intended effect of proposed sub-section 75 (3) seems to be to require the court awarding maintenance to disregard the existence of possible social security benefits. The Government is firmly of the view expressed by other speakers that primary responsibility for the support of children should rest with the parents of the children. Nevertheless, it believes that the approach taken by proposed sub-section 75 (3) is too simplistic and may create great hardships where there are not the financial resources to allow total support of two family units.

Decisions of the Family Court of Australia already hold that only where financial resources are inadequate should social security be considered. The case of F and F, (1982) FLC 91-214, for those interested, which was a decision of Mr Justice Fogarty, referred to by Senator Tate, clearly held this. It was recently reaffirmed in the case of H and H, for which the reference is (1985) FLC 91-654. There is a case for clarifying the wording of the Act to make this clear. The Government proposes to do this when the next Family Law Act is substantively amended. I interpolate that if we could guarantee a shorter debate on the Family Law Act when we did bring in an amendment we might be minded to introduce an amendment of this kind much earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can fix it up on this Bill if you give it a second reading.

—Not in the terms in which Senator Durack has advanced it. As helpful as his intentions may be, I am afraid that, as is so often the case, the execution does not match the aspiration. The Bill also proposes to add sub-section 75 (4) which purports to deal with priorities as between the needs of the party to or a child of a marriage, on the one hand, and responsibilities assumed since that marriage, on the other. The court is directed to give `such priority as is just and reasonable in all the circumstances'. This may amount to none at all or to a negative priority. No guidelines are given to determine the priority. Anything that could be encompassed by the new sub-section will already be considered under other provisions of sub-section 75 (2), including paragraph (a) which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account.

Clause 4 of the Bill amends section 87 of the Act by excluding arrangements for child maintenance from court-approved maintenance agreements. It would, in the Government's view, be a very drastic step to remove these arrangements from the scope of section 87 agreements. These agreements are a useful means for parties to finalise their affairs on marital breakdown without the trauma of continuing court proceedings. It is conceded that some of these agreements may have been structured to maximise social security receipt. Nevertheless, the Family Court in Bailey and Bailey, (1981) FLC 91-041, held that, in considering whether a maintenance agreement is proper, the Court should also consider the interests of the community at large. Again, while some legislative clarification might be useful, this will be considered in the context of other amendments to the Act.

I now turn to the question of imprisonment, the other main preoccupation or focus of Senator Durack's Bill. Clauses 5 and 6 of the Bill seek to strengthen the enforcement system by increasing the use of imprisonment for maintenance default. In the Government's view they do so in entirely inappropriate ways. Section 107 of the Act prohibits imprisonment for simple failure to comply with an order for the payment of money. It is expressed not to affect, however, the provisions of section 108 which permits imprisonment for contempt of court. Thus section 107, for example, prevents imprisonment of a person who did not have the money to pay the amount ordered. It does not prevent imprisonment of someone who has the resources but wilfully defies a court order.

The report of the National Maintenance Inquiry in 1984, which was referred to by Senator Walters and Senator Missen in their contributions, examined this topic of imprisonment in some depth-I refer to pages 311 to 320-and recommended against the repeal of section 107, while at the same time urging attitudinal changes on the part of some judges and magistrates who seemed reluctant to use their existing contempt powers in appropriate cases. The Government supports the view expressed in that inquiry and accordingly opposes the repeal of section 107. We take the absolute view that no one should be imprisoned simply because they are poor. We oppose clause 6 because it gives the judges no guidance as to what is reasonable imprisonment. We think that is necessary if any sense is to be made of this proposal.

While again acknowledging the need for action to be taken in this area, we take the view that this Bill is not the appropriate means of doing so. It will not in our view alleviate the problems of maintenance beneficiaries, and that is what it ought to be all about. I make it clear that the Government is not standing still on this issue. The question of appropriate enforcement mechanisms is being considered at the highest level by a sub-committee of Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —You started considering that three years ago. You were going to fix it up then.
—But it was not considered by a sub-committee of Cabinet then, Senator.
—But you were going to fix it up yourself.

—I was getting there. It is being considered by a sub-committee of Cabinet, chaired by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and involving the Attorney-General and other relevant Ministers. We hope to produce an integrated--
—That inspires confidence.
—I am pretty impressed. I think they are a pretty impressive lot. We hope to produce an integrated package with appropriate law reform proposals and administrative mechanisms.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Planning for Senate and House of Representatives' Chambers

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 December 1985, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the report.
upon which Senator Crichton-Browne had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after `That', insert `the Senate-
(a) accepts the necessity for the interior finish of the Senate Chamber in the new Parliament House to maintain in suitable form the dignity and atmosphere of the present Chamber;

(b) considers that it is appropriate for the new Chamber to have a basically wood-panelled appearance, taking advantage of, and making use of the wide range of timbers to be found throughout Australia; and

(c) rejects the proposal, recently revealed to Senators, for the walls of the new Chamber to be lined with fabric of varying colours, not consistent with the traditional red colour common to Westminster-style Upper Houses.'.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the interior decoration for the new Parliament House has, of course, caused a great deal of disturbance. I would like to raise a couple of matters relating to the concept of panelling in the new Parliament House, which has caused a great deal of controversy and concern to some members.
—Is there anything on which you do not have a view?

—I hope that, like the honourable senator, I will have the opportunity of being in the new Parliament House. I think everyone in this chamber should have the right to have a view. Whether it is accepted or not is beside the point. I am surprised that Senator Chipp, who apparently espouses principles that people should have a fair go, is not prepared to allow me to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to express some concern on the question of the panels and the fact that they are to be of textile. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the panels high in the chamber, which appear to me to be tired and to show the consequences of a fair degree of wear. I am not certain what fabric is involved, but it does seem to me from this point in the House that they do not seem to have worn particularly well. I hope that the sort of textile that people have in mind would not suffer the fate that the fabric in this chamber has.

There is no doubt that for reverberation purposes there is a need for great care to be shown in the panelling of the chamber. Mr President, the question you answered at Question Time today clearly indicated the importance the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House places on that, and quite rightly so. When I asked the architect yesterday whether wood panelling would cause reverberation time problems, he said that it would and that that was one of the major reasons why the move was towards the solution of fabric, apart, of course, from the cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —He also said that red would make the wood look dirty, which I thought was an extraordinary statement to make.
—The honour able senator is right.
—Order! Senator Michael Baume has the floor.

—Mr President, I am nonetheless grateful for that interjection. I am glad that at least one member of the Australian Democrats is prepared to discuss the matter seriously. The question that was concerning me, apart from the one of appearance, was one of practicality-about sound. The architect did say that it was true that straight wood panelling would create reverberation time problems, but he conceded that if there were alcoves, protrusions and lumps of wood in the wall the reverberation time problems would be resolved.
—The lumps are in the seat.

—The logs are in the seats in many instances. Many senators are much more attracted to the conventional wood panelling than to the concept of having fabric on the walls. On the other hand, I think it is absurd for the new Parliament House to be designed, like the camel, not by one committee but by committee upon committee upon committee. Senators should be very careful indeed in believing that they are the font of all knowledge and wisdom on the matter of the room that they should be working in. Nevertheless, I think it is also improper and ridiculous for those making these decisions not to listen to the wishes and desires of the people who will occupy the chamber. It is unfortunate that the options available were not provided to senators in a reasonable time and there was not the opportunity for the discussion which is now belatedly taking place. From my discussion with the architect yesterday it seemed to me that it is not possible to have wood panelling as long as it is not simply flat and without appropriate lumps and bumps, corners and protrusions such as the broadcasting box and so on, which do bounce the sound around a bit.
—And some drapes.

—And some drapes, as the honourable senator says. The opportunities are great for showing off Australian wood, just as one could argue that there is the opportunity, under the architect's present plan, for showing off some Australian textiles. But the question surely revolves around what this Senate feels is appropriate to its status and its traditions. It seems to me quite right and proper that the Senate should feel it has the capacity to have some input. If I may be critical, it is only now that the Senate has had that capacity for input and it is too late. If we insist on changes-that is, if we have the capacity to insist on changes-it will add to the cost, it will involve delay. I fear that there will be obstruction put in front of us in terms of trying to get what we want if in fact wood panelling is the majority opinion of what we want. I think also that senators have different views of the actual colour of the textile up the wall. I feel confident that it will drive many senators right up the wall.
—Some of them are up there already.

—Some of us are around the ceiling, being in free flight most of the time. I feel that it is proper for the Senate to express its concern and perhaps the hope that the Committee will make it clear to the architect-after all the Committee is the client and there can only be one client-that the end users of the chamber are far from satisfied with the nature of the interior decoration. There are plenty of comments about the carpet-the extent of black in the current carpet and whether there is such a thing as a traditional carpet. The House of Lords, as I remember, burnt down in the early nineteenth century and none of the original carpet was kept on record so that we could see what a really long tradition is all about. There seems to be an accepted view in the Senate of what is Senate red and that is a deeper red, a richer red and a stronger red than the pink which is intended to be put on the walls.

SPEECH.PARA: I express my concern that the chamber is not as I would have hoped it might be. I think there is a great case for incorporating wood in the panelling-not flatwood panelling which seems to be the modern trend, but a panelling that gives us an opportunity to see displayed the skills of Australian craftsmen and the particular beauties of Australian wood. The way we must go about it is simply to make a request to the client rather than to harass the architect.

The experience of the Sydney Opera House and the problems that emerged there were clearly because there was no evident single client with whom the architect could continually relate. We have to avoid any situation emerging in this construction where the Senate, the House of Representatives or anyone else considers himself to be the client and takes unto himself the right to demand and instruct the architect on what is right and what is wrong. I believe that we have the right to complain a little to the client-acting on our behalf and on behalf of all Australians, but on our behalf to the extent that we will be using the chamber-that our wishes have been ignored and that we did not have an opportunity at an appropriate time, before this went so far down the track, to have any input on the decision between wood and textile. Having looked at what appear to be textile panels at the top of this chamber, which I presume are for acoustic purposes--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are to soak up the water when the rain comes in.

—We hope that that is one problem we will not have in the new and permanent Parliament House. Perhaps architects now have worked out how to put roofs that work on buildings. If those panels are an accurate reflection of what happens to textiles over time-if developments have taken place such that we are to be locked in to the textile decision-I hope that those panels are not the sort of thing that will appear in our new chamber. I stress that in my view the pink colour is unattractive. It does, I regret to say, remind me of some senators' eyes early in the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —An old colleague of mine, who was getting towards the end of his career when I came into this place, was former Senator Cavanagh. I understand that when there were discussions about where the new Parliament House would be built-that was before the time I came in-he used to say, a little facetiously: `I don't care where it is as long as I'm in it'. I think that Senator Cavanagh probably facetiously would say something like that today: `I don't care what it is like, as long as I'm in it'. That would have been Jim Cavanagh's facetious comment, but I think he would have taken this matter quite seriously. Some of us might not be in that Parliament although we probably all hope that we will be. I suppose 20 years from now none of us will be in it. We are building it not for this Parliament but parliaments of the future; for those people who will represent the people in the national Parliament long after we have gone. I am on the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House.
—True confessions.

—It might be a true confession, but I am probably taking a lot more interest in this matter than a lot of other people in the chamber because of the fact that I have been on that Committee for a long time. I take my role seriously, as one who should be doing his best to make sure that the Parliament we will occupy in a couple of years time is a fit place for the national representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: In my role as a member of the Committee I have listened to many arguments, not only on the particular matter we are talking about today. I have had differing opinions when things have first been brought before us. After hearing the arguments of those people, who know much better than I do the technicalities of the matter, I have been swayed to accept the arguments. On some occasions the arguments of the Committee have been accepted by the architects and all of those associated with the construction, so it has been a two-way street. We do not come in to the Committee with any pre-conceived ideas and stick to those pre-conceived ideas if we see that the evidence is overwhelming on the opposite side. Let us look at the amendment before us. The first part states:
. . . the Senate-
(a) accepts the necessity for the interior finish of the Senate Chamber in the new Parliament House to maintain in suitable form the dignity and atmosphere of the present Chamber. . .

I suppose that we could not build another chamber which will have exactly the same sort of dignity and atmosphere. I put to the Senate that we will have a dignity in the new chamber, if it is constructed and decorated in the way that we have outlined in the report and as has been shown to us in the model in King's Hall. I do not think that we have to worry about the dignity and atmosphere of the future chamber. Certainly the atmosphere will be different because it will be a larger chamber. I would hope that the dignity will be more than the dignity we sometimes see in this chamber. The next part of the amendment states:

. . . the Senate . . . considers that it is appropriate for the new Chamber to have a basically wood-panelled appearance, taking advantage of, and making use of the wide range of timbers to be found throughout Australia. . .

Why is it appropriate? I suppose it would be nice for us to have the idea that we would be able to use wood products grown in Australia to make it a truly national chamber, or something like that, but that is about the only reason that has been put forward. Part (c) of the amendment, which is tied in with part (b), states:

. . . rejects the proposal, recently revealed to Senators, for the walls of the new Chamber to be lined with fabric of varying colours, not consistent with the traditional red colour common to Westminster-style Upper Houses.

I have heard the arguments on a number of occasions in the Committee about the necessity for fabric walls and I accept them. When the Committee meets tomorrow, if this matter is brought before it, I will still be accepting them. If those in the chamber who do not like that sort of attitude from one of their representatives feel highly incensed about it they can make moves to take me off the Committee. I will stick to the original proposal because I think it is fine. The arguments that have been put before us have been cogent arguments that this sort of finish is necessary. In conclusion, I will say something about the traditional red colour. The amendment states:
. . . not consistent with the traditional red colour common to Westminster-style Upper Houses.

What is the traditional colour? We are not sure. We think that this is perhaps the traditional colour. If one goes to those States of Australia which have upper houses-there is no longer an upper house in Queensland-one will see that the colour varies from State Parliament to State Parliament. Anyway, why should not we, as the Australian Parliament, set a pattern which will be followed in Australia? Why do we have to be hide-bound to a colour which might have been in the House of Lords at some stage? We have different reds in this country and there is no reason why we should not use a colour which is slightly different from the one we have been used to. If this matter is discussed by the Committee tomorrow, I will be putting forward my view that the decision made by the Committee previous to this discussion should hold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that we should consider what we require in the new Senate chamber in the new Parliament House. I suggest that we require, firstly, that the Senate chamber should be functionally efficient, not least in the area of acoustics. We want an elegant chamber which will recognise traditions-not necessarily British traditions. We have our own traditions now and we want to recognise the traditions we have established. Finally, it has to be one which will stand the test of time, not one which is trendy for a particular period, whether it is the 1980s, or for that matter the 1880s. We have to have a chamber which will last for a long time. Others may have different impressions but I think these requirements are adequately expressed in the brief given to the architects and interior design consultants.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House was appointed by us and is supposed to supervise these things. It is now proposed that we should impose on that Committee's design brief some particular extra requirements of our own. I would submit that we have no skills in this chamber in the relevant disciplines. It seems to me that we do not have skills to fit out a room that will be lofty and artificially lit. I do not think we have the relevant skills in acoustics. These are very important matters.

In the past we have delegated to experts the job of meeting broadly expressed requirements. I watched with interest when this sort of worry occurred in respect of the magnificent Victorian Arts Centre. There was a great deal of worry about whether the interior decorating was going to be a success. In fact, it has turned out to be a magnificent success. However, let us suppose that the Victorian Parliament had taken on itself to give a direction to the architects that the main theatre was to be as near as possible to the design and style as of the Princess Theatre of the 1870s. That would have been an absurd direction. We are very nearly saying the same thing. What we want to ensure is that this building will stand the test of time. We have given an appropriate direction. We have employed experts to do this. I think we meddle at our peril and at the peril of the design of the building itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to make only a brief contribution. I have just been chairing a discussion group of members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and United States State Department officials. We were discussing the South Pacific nuclear free zone. I told the group that I had to leave to come to this chamber because we were going to take a vote on what the colour of the new Senate chamber walls will be. I do not think that went down particularly well.

SPEECH.PARA: I was irritated by Senator Michael Baume's contribution this afternoon. The honourable senator was really saying that somehow those of us who were elected to the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House have not done our job. I was elected to the Committee in July 1981 and I have served on it ever since. Senator Colston was also elected in July 1981 and is still a member of the Committee. Senator Reid was elected early in 1983. I mention that because Senator Reid has been an excellent member of the Committee and she has a much better attendance record at committee meetings than I have. I think all honourable senators should read the speech that she made on this matter last December.

In May 1982 the Committee approved the design proposals for the Senate chamber. The interior design was finalised and approved by the Committee in 1984 and 1985. The presentation was made to honourable senators in mid-September 1985. Maybe that is where we went wrong. I am not going to argue about the acoustics or the lighting this afternoon because, quite frankly, I have had to rely on the experts in this field. However, that does not mean that the Committee has rubber stamped all the decisions of the experts.

The Committee has heard lots of arguments and debate. I will just mention a few. Early on we debated at some length whether all the tennis courts would be located on the Senate side or whether some would be on the House of Representatives side of the building. That might not sound a very big issue, but the debate about that went on for some months. We had an argument about a child care centre. We debated whether such a facility would be included in the building. I see that this matter is listed on the business paper for tomorrow. To my knowledge, we have been perhaps not arguing but making decisions about a child care centre for about two years. This debate is still going on. We have had differences of opinion over what sort of crockery and cutlery should be put in the new Parliament House. Car parking involves the expenditure of millions of dollars. We had to make decisions on how many car parking spaces ought to be provided, where they ought to be and so on. I mention these matters which have been debated for a long time.

I was elected-or I believe I was elected-to represent all senators on that Committee. Therefore, I do not think we should debate all of the issues in this chamber. I mentioned the consideration that the Committee has given to child care facilities. I think a debate on that matter in this chamber would run for some days. I have gone back through all of the papers since the debate that took place last December. I have read what the architects and all the others have said. I am convinced that if we alter the decision we will increase the cost. I know that some people would ask why we cannot do that if we are going to spend $800m anyway. However, I also believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much are the paintings costing?

—I should not answer interjections, but I will say that I do not know the cost of the paintings. However, I believe that a large number of them will be provided by the Australian National Gallery on a rotation basis. One thing I am sure of is that if we make a decision that is contrary to the one that was recommended to the Committee we will delay the finalisation of the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask all Opposition senators to read Senator Reid's speech. We are talking about Australia and we are not trying to follow the design of the Westminster building. The new Parliament House is a unique building. I believe that when finished it will prove to be one of the world's great buildings. Like Senator Colston, I know how I am going to vote today. More importantly, I know how I am going to vote on the Committee tomorrow where my vote counts. Quite frankly, nothing that anybody might say this afternoon will convince me to change my vote. I am sticking with the recommendation that has been made. Senator Colston has already said that he is going to vote in this way. I would expect that some members of the Committee from the other side of the chamber are also of that opinion. When this matter is resolved we will be able to get on and finish the building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express concerns in three areas, namely, choice of textiles; lack of evidence of linkages with the States, recognising that this is a States rights House; and a lack of historical visual evidence of Australian traditions. Firstly, I believe that we are going to have problems with the choice of the textiles chosen and the positioning of those textiles. We will also have problems in respect of colour and texture. The pattern chosen is one of modern craft design and will not give any symbolic historical links. There will certainly be many difficulties in regard to the collection of dust and cleaning will be a major problem. Of course, the fabric will tend to deteriorate in time.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is unfortunate that the architects have not recognised that not only is the Senate a House of review but also it is a States House. I think there is evidence of this behind the presidential chair. The timbers throughout this building have been taken from all the States. I think it would be unfortunate if we lost that sense of identity with the States. I would like to see the presidential chair and the surrounds for about five to six feet in length and six feet in height behind it incorporated into the new design if possible. I think the new Senate chamber should reflect a continuity of our history. I think it is unfortunate that there is not a lot of evidence in the architectural design of the new chamber of linkages with the past and of important things that have happened. I believe that the new chamber has a somewhat modern and austere look. Festival Hall in London certainly has this quality. That building functions pretty well but it is not aesthetically pleasing to the eye. I would like the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House to consider the matters that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to report a conversion. I have come to the view, moved only by the evidence of my own eyes, that there is sufficient merit in the proposal put to honourable senators in the display in King's Hall for me to support the proposal. In speaking of that conversion, I want to emphasise that I am not at all impressed by threats that any other view would lead to undue delay or additional cost of the new Parliament House. As far as I am concerned, that is not an argument and should never have been put forward in certain material that has been distributed to us. It is an insult to try to blackmail us by using that sort of argument.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the debate that look place last December, for the first time we have had presented to us-the people who will actually live and work in this environment day by day-the textiles that are proposed for the wall surrounding the Senate chamber itself. The display that has been presented and the model that has been put on show give one some idea of the scope of the carpet area in particular and the way in which the fabric will cover portions of the chamber. This will be but a part of the overall area surrounding the Senate chamber and the galleries. This demonstration shows that the fabric does have merit. At night, in King's Hall, the fabric takes on a colour which is very beautiful indeed. It has a very deep, rich tone which I find very attractive. Under the very harsh morning light from a skylight in King's Hall which seems to mediate the strong sunlight through a bluey-grey filter, it looks horrible. But I have been assured by those who have been responsible for the display that that type of mediation of the strong Australian sunlight will not be the type of light that reaches that area of the Senate chamber. There will be a mixture of natural and artifical light, and it will not be of that colouring to bring out, I think, unduly or in an emphasised way the pinks that we have in the early morning viewing of that fabric.

I believe that the Press, when it took up and reported the debate last December, did not sufficiently convey some of the exaggeration and the humour of that occasion at the end of the session and took it all far too seriously. I do not regret having spoken in that way, but with the evidence having been presented to my own eyes I now find that I can support the proposal that has been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some diffidence that I speak on this issue because I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. In one way honourable senators could argue that as a member of that Committee I should not be canvassing a point of view, but should be reflecting the views of one's colleagues. Senator Colston and Senator Sibraa have entered the debate and I feel that it is valid for me to put some of the information I have gained while I have been on the Committee to the Senate. I compliment Senator Sibraa on his honesty because during the period I have been on the Parliament House Committee I cannot recall having seen Senator Sibraa at one of the meetings, and I am glad he referred to and acknowledged that in his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I happen to have an old-fashioned view that architects serve the client. One ought to try to satisfy the interests and desires of the client. One would have to be particularly insensitive in this chamber not to recognise the degree of controversy that the proposals have occasioned amongst our fellow senators. Whether they are right or wrong is not the issue. The point is that a very high level of concern has been demonstrated after the belated display of what the design of the chamber was going to be to the members of the Senate. It is on that basis that I think this debate is justified. One of the difficulties we face is that the Senate is not the client. The client is the Parliament House Construction Authority, but the Authority does have to, indirectly, take some notice of what we are saying. Whether we are going to be able to reverse this decision, if that is the wish of the majority of the members of the Senate, the debate and the portrayal of points of view is worth having. I regret that the architects and the Authority left it so late in the day before they had the common sense or the courtesy to approach the client which would have been an elementary thing to do.

In dealing with the new Senate chamber, the first thing the Senate must appreciate is that there has been a great mistake made, not with the furnishings but with the size of the chamber. I do not know who was responsible for that. Whether it was the result of the brief given to the architects or the Authority in the first instance, or whether the architects took it upon themselves to design a chamber as large as that, we are faced with a chamber that is considerably larger than the present one. We are faced with a chamber which for one day every three years will accommodate not only the senators but all the members of the House of Representatives. That has given us a chamber that is very large and it will lack the intimacy that this chamber has. That is the fundamental problem we are facing. The United States Senate is quite a small chamber. The House of Commons has 600 members, but nearly half of them cannot get a seat in the chamber; this preserves the intimacy which is very important for the debates that take place. There is nothing we can do about the new chamber; it is literally set in concrete. It is poured and there is not a damn thing any of us can do about altering the size of it.

I will move to one of the most powerful arguments that has been advanced by the advisers on the use of fabrics on the walls. We have been told that that is because of reverberation. I do not wish to go through the technicalities of it, but bluntly, that is arrant nonsense. The great concert chambers of the world are lined either with wood or most commonly with a rendered concrete finish. I am very surprised that an architectural firm that hails from New York has not taken the time to go through the Lincoln Centre, or paid the money to go to the magnificent Metropolitan Opera and been in that quite huge auditorium there. It may be that our architects do not have any cultural pursuits-I do not know. All the great concert halls of the world are not lined with fabric and the acoustics are at a premium in those chambers.

If we need any further confirmation of the difficulty that the architects are in with respect to reverberation or acoustics in the chamber, we have to have a look at what is not shown on the model and look at the overhead display of microphones. The cats cradle that we have up there is visually unacceptable but it seems that this is a necessary dictate because of the acoustics of the chamber. One of the other justifications for the choice of colours relates to the great red centre of Australia. We are in the business of being parliamentarians, not denizens of the centre of Australia. With respect, the colours of the great Australian outback have absolutely nothing to do with the colours used in the House of Representatives or the colours used in the Senate chamber. My great fear about this is that we have designed a chamber that not only will be number one off the rank for the architectural prize of 1988 but also because of its inherent design, will date very rapidly. It is going to be passe within a few years and it is going to be very much last year's effort. All of us here and our successors will be using that chamber, not for ten years or fifty years, but I hope that it will last the people of Australia for some hundreds of years, and it requires a different vision to the vision that has been placed on it at present.

The final point I make is the matter of cost. Undeniably a penalty would be involved in not proceeding with that present design, but if wood panelling was substituted for fabric I do not believe that the cost increase would be more than very marginal. We are not going to buy those specially woven wool fabrics for a handful of beans. It will have to be a special weaving job, and quite a few square feet of surface is involved. The net extra cost of using wood panelling will not be terribly much. While I am on the question of cost, there are areas of waste that can be picked up. We have an Art Acquisitions Committee which is going around all the basket makers of Balmain, or whatever Mr Keating calls them, buying objects d'art, folk art, and all that sort of thing which again will date very rapidly, to furnish the members and senators rooms, and the hallways. As somebody said before, the Australian National Gallery has more pictures that it can ever display, and there are other pictorial assets that the Commonwealth has which can be used to furnish the new House. If we are short of a few dollars we can easily pick money up from those sort of activities to provide an environment which the Senate wants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the debate has been interpreted by some members of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House as an attack on them, their integrity, their taste or anything else. I do not think that was intended, although the rather hurt comments from some members of the Committee would certainly have led me to believe that they felt that this was some kind of personal attack. It is not. I think it is a mixture of our feeling in some way left out, although the Committee members were representing us, and in other ways our concern about the sort of heritage that we are providing for, not only for future members of parliament but also for the future citizens of Australia for whom I think this is an essential part of their heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that many of us here fit into the category of not knowing much about architecture, but we do know what we feel comfortable in. That in itself is a reasonable attitude to take. After all, we are often in here 12 hours a day. We are, therefore, the ones most concerned with our surroundings. I spoke to the architect yesterday morning and he told me that he thought this was the ugliest chamber he had ever seen, which got my back up to start with, although I was not being terribly tactful myself about the display. So I guess it was a bit of giving and taking.

TALK.START.PARA: —He really meant the inhabitants.
—No. He followed that up by telling me that one cannot have red with wood because it makes the wood look dirty.
—He told me green.

—He did go on to tell me that if one changes the colour of red one has to mix it with green and a whole lot of things which I have long since forgotten from the days when I did physics. He said that this was an ugly chamber and that wood looks dirty if it is put with red. Looking around here, perhaps it needs a bit of a clean, but I cannot see anything terribly wrong with it.
—Some Mr Sheen.

—A bit of Mr Sheen, as Senator Withers says. I do not think that this is an ugly chamber. The first time I set foot in here I felt a very welcoming influence, not necessarily from the people, although they certainly helped.
—I was good to you.
—Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was indeed welcoming. It is a chamber that is immediately welcoming. I take Senator MacGibbon's point that we are moving into a much larger chamber.
—Jim Cavanagh used to say it didn't matter where it was so long as he was in it.

—Indeed he did. Perhaps it will be a much less welcoming chamber. The point is that all of us will be in there for hours on end and we have to feel at home. As far as the consultation process is concerned, I know that many of us took part in sitting upon the prototype chairs which were provided to us last year. I think that many of us felt decidedly unhappy with those. They had drawers underneath and to get at them one had to get down on the floor. There were pull-out tops to the tables with which one could have taken off one's kneecap or some other part of one's anatomy if one's knee was not in the road. There were steel runners on the drawers that could have chopped off one's fingers when one put them back in. There was a back to the seat that was so inflexible that I think most of us would have had bad backs by the end of a long Committee session.
—Life wasn't meant to be easy.

—It was not going to be easy in that seat. Most of us would have felt much older than our years after a very short time. I understand that there is now another prototype. I wonder why we did not just go to a car manufacturer. After all, car manufacturers are in the business of making comfortable seating for those of us who sit in cars for a long time, travel long distances and so on. Anyway, I was assured that it was all ergonometrically done or whatever the expression is, but it seemed that the comfort was about the same as the word-that is, rather awful. Those senators who complained and had it withdrawn did a service not only to us but also to future generations of politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: Somebody asked me a little while ago whether I was a woody or a weavey. I guess that I am a woody. I have no objection to woven fabric. I just do not happen to think that it is particularly appropriate on the walls of a chamber, however vast Senator MacGibbon describes it. I would have thought that there were sufficient varieties of wood in Australia for us to be able to use them to make the place feel as welcoming as this chamber has always been. Certainly, enough of our timber fits into the endangered species category for us to want to preserve it for our children and our children's children. There are traditions to be observed. One speaker opposite-I forgot who it was; it may have been Senator Watson-said that they are Australian traditions, not necessarily British or Westminster traditions, and the use of our timber will probably be a much more lasting tradition than getting the colours of a piece of fabric to change four or five times a day in the same pattern as Ayers Rock does under various lights, which is apparently what all of this is about.

We face other problems too with having a fabric-lined chamber. The question of cleaning has already been raised. One presumes the colour will fade over time. It will inevitably wear out and require replacement. Even if bolts of the fabric are retained for that purpose, any woman who has ever let down a hem on a skirt will know that the change is very visible to anybody who cares to cast an eye over it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The change in the fabric, do you mean?

—Yes, because some parts of it have been exposed to more light than others. With natural light coming into the chamber, we leave ourselves wide open to all the fading problems that occur in natural light. Inevitably, after a period of years, various sections of the chamber walls will be in different coloured fabric, although the fabric is allegedly the same. I am not roused to great passion over all of this. If we are to have a new and permanent Parliament House it might just as well be one in which we are all comfortable, which is efficient and effective, which has good acoustics, which is redolent of Australia's heritage and which will allow future generations to know that the Australian Parliament, in this era at least, was concerned about our own traditions and heritage as well as our comfort and the colour of the blasted carpet.

—I feel it is our duty to say a few words and to express our views on this subject. As posterity comes along people can then point the bone at us and show us where we were wrong, but at least we will have spoken. I refer to Senator Tate's very reckless attitude today to telling the truth by saying that he has changed his mind, which is a very unusual thing for a senator to do. I think it is to his credit that he has done that. Frankly I have changed my mind. My initial impression-
—Are you a woody or a weavey?

—I am more of a woody than a weavey, but I am not prepared to go to the wall on it. Originally I was a dyed in the wool conservative tory, who favoured the traditional red, the Westminster traditions, and who likes this old chamber. My natural reactions were in favour of those who did not like what was being suggested. Frankly I think that one must take a lot of notice of what the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House has decided. I served on that Committee for about eight years, until a couple of years ago when there was a great rush and push and I fell off it. During that time I saw that members of the Committee did a lot of work on it. They obtained advice from architects who knew something about the matter. We are rank amateurs. We know what we like, but we do not really know much about the questions of colour and so forth. I believe that we cannot set ourselves up against the experts, nor against the advice which the Committee has taken.
—You have spent a lifetime defying experts; why stop now?

—Not on colour. I have heard the architects talk about the strange effects of the colour red on people and so on. I never knew that those sorts of things happened in this chamber. Nonetheless, I think that one has to make up one's mind about it. I think that the modern style, the designs and the lighter colourings which have been suggested, although it is regrettable that we do not have the other colours, are things which we must accept.
—Why?
—I am convinced that we need a lighter tone. We cannot have dark red and wood in this larger chamber, because of the acoustics.
—That's not true.

—I am sorry, but that is what the architects said to us in discussion. Let me say this to Senator MacGibbon: Although the new Senate chamber is larger than this one, that is not because on one day in every three years members of both Houses will have to be accommodated in it. At the moment the House of Representatives and the Senate are identical in size. In future the House of Representatives will be larger than the Senate, but the Senate will be larger than it is now. That means that there are problems which have to be met and given close attention by those who are responsible for designing it. Therefore, I do not believe we should delay this matter any longer. We should accept what has come to us from the Committee and agree to the designs. I believe that the designs, seen in context, will be rather attractive. I do not believe that the House of Representatives can be completely different from the Senate. Both will have this graduated colour. It would be strange if we had this unique little eighteenth century Senate and a twentieth century House of Representatives. If it were the other way round I might be agreeable to it, but as it is I do not think we should go in that direction. I think we should accept what is suggested and defeat this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I had better declare what I am-I am a woody, and what is more I am a Tasmanian woody because I believe that people from my State really appreciate the timbers. Anyone who has built a home-recently or in the past-will know that usually there is an argument with the architect. The architect usually has definite ideas one way or the other and the person whose home it is wants to tie the design in with his or her own way of living, likes and dislikes. As Senator Haines said so well, if one wants a place in which one feels comfortable then of necessity one must introduce one's own likes and dislikes. Otherwise we should all be living in homes built by experts and would probably end up with little boxes on the hillside.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen and spoken to the architects of the new building and we have now reached the situation where a lot of us simply do not agree with them. There is no harm at all in saying to the architects `Alter this bit' or `Alter that; you are right here, but you are wrong there'. Surely we can have some say in the design of a chamber in which we will spend many, many hours. Senator Haines is right when she says that red is a very difficult colour. It is difficult to ensure that it does not fade. The central lighting, which is natural lighting, will certainly make the colour fade and Senator Watson, who has great expertise in textiles, has already said that the material will gather dust because the particular weave is one that is prone to gathering dust. In a number of years it will look shoddy and it will go out of date. We have realised from our experience with this place that timber only improves in looks over the years, whereas material certainly does not. I suggest that we be allowed to have some say in a chamber in which we will spend many hours in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I draw the attention of senators to the fact that this debate will end at 5.38 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This might be the first time that we get a gag motion through without much trouble! I simply take the opportunity to rise for a very few minutes to make my comments, which are not dissimilar from those that I made on the last occasion that I spoke on this matter. Senator MacGibbon said that there was considerable difference of opinion and that a lot of passion had been raised about this issue. I think that is the sort of thing that happens when a whole lot of non-experts insist on having their say on things about which they are quite clearly not well informed. It is quite reasonable for us to be consulted, but ultimately the decision about these matters should go back to the experts. None of us would have any understanding of colour as has Mr Travis, who took us through the display the other day. We can say what we like or what we do not like, but his expertise gives him the ability to talk about the effect of colours in space, the effect of colours under light, and so on. For the record I must say that I am delighted with the colours that were displayed in the exhibition in King's Hall. I think they go very much to the colours of the heart of Australia and, for that reason, I like them very much.

SPEECH.PARA: None of this, of course, means that I am dissatisfied with the present chamber, but none of us were consulted as to how this was designed and we have just accommodated to it. I presume that that is what will happen when we all arrive in the next chamber. It is most important to realise that we are not experts and we do not understand the scientific and significant discoveries about the acoustic requirements of the chamber, much less its colour requirements. Experts are employed at considerable cost to make those decisions on behalf of the Parliament House Construction Authority and I do not see that any of us are better placed than the experts in that Authority to do anything more than give an opinion and make some comment. Ultimately it is those people with the professional skills who will make the final decision on our behalf.

I find no trouble dealing with the idea of fabric on walls. Any number of buildings in Australia for any number of years have had fabrics of many varieties, from suede to wool, on their walls and these seem to be no more difficult than any other material. I can see that my comments are absolutely gripping the Senate's attention! Honourable senators are vastly caught up with what I am saying! SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important that we have a vote today because if we do not we will not reflect the views of the Senate to the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. I will take up very quickly the point that was made by Senator Sibraa. It was never the intention of this motion or the mover of it that the resolution be one that directs the Committee; rather it was intended to be indicative and a reflection of the views of senators about the interior design of the new Senate chamber. That is further reinforced by the fact that both the Whip from the Labor Party and the Whip from the Liberal Party sent out circulars to all senators asking them to indicate their preference. I assume that the purpose of that exercise was to indicate in some way--
—I did not get one.

—Well, perhaps yours got lost or was filled in by someone else; they were certainly sent out. The purpose of the circulars was to indicate the general views about the new chamber. A considerable number of those circulars were not filled in and returned; so at least we are now giving senators a chance to make a judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, as my amendment indicates, I enjoy the environment in which we presently work and operate. I am not saying that I am so fixed and rigid that I am not prepared to see some sort of compromise. In fact I am reminded of the High Court and the fact that when the then Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick, was told that he could not have wooden panelling because the acoustics would be intolerable, he said `Well you find a solution', and the solution was found. If one looks at the recommendations for the new chamber one sees under the acoustic assessment of the scale model of the Senate chamber that it was clearly demonstrated that the answer might be in the form of a discreetly slotted timber panel system over minimum depth of 50 mm of fibreglass or mineral wall. Then it goes on to talk about a preferred system which would utilise cloth-faced modular treatment over similar materials. In other words, the report is telling us that we can have timber. The acoustics have been tested and it has been found that timber is suitable. What was set out in King's Hall yesterday was, I think, patently dishonest, or at least what was said to me by two gentlemen who were there. We have an option. One ought not be confused or confounded by what has been put to us by those who were briefing or debriefing people yesterday. I was interested to note also that originally the suggestion was that we would have the proposed colour because it was Pilbara red, or Pilbara pink, as I think it was described. Having lived in the Pilbara for six years I can tell honourable senators that it bears no relationship. Having pointed that out to the architects they have now changed it. It is now a gum tree red, because apparently that is something slightly less disputable.

I, for my part, am not satisfied that architects are the repository of all knowledge and all wisdom. I have had enough architects doing enough buildings for me to know that they have one obsession in life, which is never to do the same thing twice. They believe that if one is going to build a Senate chamber one should make sure of one thing: One should cast one's own personality, one's own character, one's own style and one's own influence on it. One should make sure that it does not look like anything ever done by anyone else before. So the architects and the good little artists out there yesterday have been quite certain to ensure that they do something which will stamp on the new Parliament House their design. They will not have a reflection of tradition, of style, of previous culture, the views of the Senate or anything which vaguely resembles that which has gone on in the past and which we have seen before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what they will want next: An entirely new set of senators.

—With modest exceptions I am not so hung up about that. It depends on who the exceptions are. Yesterday I was so impertinent as to suggest in one of my lighter moments that the colours remind me of what I perceive to be the inside of a women's loo in a Coles cafeteria.
—When were you last in the women's toilet at a Coles cafeteria?

—I said `I perceive'. I must say that with a couple I was talking to yesterday I was probably getting closer to a women's loo than they would have been. Yesterday those people took grave exception to my judgments because I did not agree with them. I think that there is a blind commitment to ensure that what we get is totally different to that which we presently have. In fact, one of the gentlemen there said that most of us were colour blind anyway and that we did not see the colour. I tried to explain that the colour is in the eye of the beholder. It is how one sees the colour that counts, not how other people see it. I thought that was a startling revelation to make. It is hardly a reason for arguing in support of the proposition that is put.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that the material which they see above them is material put up there for the purpose of ensuring some acoustic protection. Honourable senators can see the marvellous benefit of that faded, grotty, dirty material. Now we want to have both the side walls and back walls in the new Parliament House a vulgar common pink which will be subject to daylight and which will fade, which will attract dust and which, as Senator Haines quite properly and sensibly said, will not be able to be replaced because the colour will change as time goes on. Of course, besides anything else we all know it will date.

I really hope that the vote taken this afternoon will not be steeped in prejudice. I hope it is not a vote that will create a dichotomy between the traditionalists and the new enlightened. I hope that honourable senators will make a serious judgment based on what is best, most suitable, most accommodating and most satisfactory for this chamber. It is not an argument between the eighteenth century Whigs and Tories. I am sorry that I get the distinct impression that there is likely to be a dichotomy between one side and the other. I would hate to think that there is a de facto Caucus on one side and a free vote on this side. So, if the vote is held on the other side and if enlightened senators on this side move across, of course we are bound to lose the vote. I hope that we see some courage, integrity and honesty and that we do not see the sort of dichotomy which is inevitable in these sorts of situations. I put it to honourable senators that there are some excellent reasons for maintaining the basic traditions of this chamber in terms of the colour of the carpet, the colour of the seats, the style of the seats and the walls. The walls do not have to be all wood. They can be a nice mixture. Clearly we are running out of time. I hope we can get this matter to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were debating this matter just before lunch I raised the question of the Government's policy as enunciated by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) in this chamber yesterday in answer to a question about the way in which the Government proposes to handle the application of the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights Commission legislation to the problem, as it sees it, of the State electoral laws. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, if passed, will give it the power of investigation into State laws and the acts and practices of State officials. The Minister said that it will be invited to make a report on the State electoral laws which may offend the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister went on to say that the Government had some expectations, at the very least, of receiving a report that the State electoral laws, or some of them, were in conflict with the International Covenant or the Bill of Rights, which has adopted the same wording, and that then the Commonwealth would give the States an opportunity of correcting those laws to bring them in conformity with the guarantee in the Bill of Rights and, if they did not, the Commonwealth would fix it up by legislation introduced into this Parliament. The statement which Senator Gareth Evans made yesterday was also put to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who did not seem to be quite so forthcoming in revealing the Government's policy. Thanks to Senator Evans we do have the full revelation of the deal that has been done in Caucus to pacify the legal back bench committee which has been demanding legislation to deal directly with State electoral laws and also to try to satisfy the demands of the Australian Democrats.

I noticed in one of the papers today that the Government's proposal, as enuniciated by Senator Evans, has already drawn a very strong reaction from the Premier of Western Australia. Perhaps the Government will start to revise its ideas if one State Labor Premier after another sees this as the thin end of the wedge, as no doubt they will. No matter what they might think about their electoral laws-we know Mr Burke is very critical of the Western Australian electoral laws-and whatever they may think of the Premier of Queensland and Queensland electoral laws, they will all understand the threat to their independence which this proceeding of the Federal Government will entail. It is quite clear that if the Federal Government gives in to the present campaign against Queensland and Western Australian electoral laws and ultimately uses the power of this Parliament under the external affairs powers as interpreted by the High Court of Australia in the Franklin Dam case to impose the will of this Parliament on the States in relation to their electoral laws, that can be done in respect of any other State laws which can, in some way, be seen to be in conflict with the International Covenant. We do not even need to have the Bill of Rights to do that; it can be done even if the Bill of Rights legislation never passes this Parliament.

The new policy or deal which has been revealed by Senator Evans to its full extent does raise an absolutely fundamental question on the whole package of legislation. It is not something new; it has been well thought out. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, foreshadowed that the Government would do this sort of thing some months ago. Strangely enough the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) only a few weeks ago when he was up in Queensland said: `Oh, no, we would never do that. We would never pass Federal legislation which would apply to State electoral laws'. Apparently Mr Young was not really across what the Government thinking was-or whatever it was, it has now changed-as the Government has clearly embarked upon a course of applying the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights or the Bill of Rights, if it is passed, as a means of imposing Federal legislation on the States in the whole area that may be covered by the Covenant or the Bill of Rights. It is totally hypocritical for the Government to draft the legislation in such a way. The Government has said that the legislation does not apply to State laws or to acts and practices of State governments and that all it can do under the Bill is to seek a report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on State acts and practices.

The Government obviously has been pulling the wool over the eyes of the State Labor Premiers in this regard, who have not really seen the significance of what the Government is about. Now it is there for all to see. Senator Evans's statement yesterday, which has had wide publicity and has already drawn a very strong riposte from the Premier of Western Australia, reveals the real and true attempt by this Government to change the Federal Constitution, not by going to the people in a referendum but by this back door method of seeking reports from the Human Rights Commission and using those reports-if it finds that the State law is inconsistent with the guarantee in the covenant or the Bill of Rights-as justification for Federal legislation to apply directly to the States and to override State laws.

The true purpose of this legislation was revealed clearly by Senator Evans's answer in the Senate yesterday. I asked Senator Evans about this and I got an offhand reply. I think he was hoping that the Bill would go through smoothly before lunch and he did not want to delay it. I raised with him the question of whether or not this legislation will mean that the Government will be able-it will be forced by pressures on it, as it has been forced in relation to State electoral laws maybe in relation to other State laws-to legislate to override State laws. The Government may not have to be forced much because I think it wants to do it, but it wants to have some degree of respectability by having a report from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission so that it can say: `Here we are, we are justified in the action we are taking'.

The fact of the matter is that it is not just State electoral laws. We know what head of steam is raised about other State laws, particularly laws relating to public assembly in Queensland and Western Australia. No doubt in other States where these things have arisen, those laws may be found to be contrary to the guarantee in the Covenant. Many other State laws could be found by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to be contrary to the Covenant, depending on who is appointed to that Commission. This Bill will be the vehicle and principal instrument by which the Bill of Rights will be applied directly-even though there will be a circuitous route before it is applied-to State laws.

Let there be no mistake about it; on more and more occasions there will be Federal laws overriding State laws which, except for the wide interpretation of the external affairs power in the Franklin Dam case, are certainly not within the power of this Parliament. The Bill of Rights will be used to make a fundamental change to our Constitution and federal system. It will not be done directly by referendum, by the will and consent of the people, but it will be achieved in this indirect, devious and dubious way so that this Government can achieve the long-standing objects which it knows that it cannot hope to achieve by a referendum which is put to the people in their full knowledge after full debate. The Government will achieve this major change in our Constitution by those methods.

What I can say to Senator Durack is that I think it is generally acknowledged that the electoral guarantee question is probably the most important and immediately compelling area for government action of this kind at the moment. They are absolutely fundamental, in many ways more fundamental than many other rights or classes of rights. TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to respond to Senator Durack's invitation. What the Opposition is inviting the Government to do is to brush aside in a thoroughly brutish and insensitive way the processes of open consultation and input from the States which we would not contemplate ignoring. He is inviting us to rush to judgment on the difficult, technical and legal issues involved without fully and carefully weighing and evaluating them; and giving them the care and attention to detail and over the time span that we know he would himself. I simply indicate that I am shocked at the suggestion that he makes. It does not reflect the deep and intense commitment that I know he has to democratic values and the values of open government. I indicate to him that, compelling as he may have thought his lullaby may have been, we will resist his siren song on this occasion.

—I thank the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) for his answer to my previous question and draw his attention to section 9 (1) (d) of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 which, I remind the Senate, is one of Senator Durack's splendid pieces of legislation. On my reading, that provision is duplicated in clause 11 (1) (k) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill. Is that not sufficient to undertake an inquiry into State legislation? Was it not the case that the Human Rights Commission undertook an inquiry into the electricity situation in Queensland which would have been possible, without the Australian Bill of Rights Bill, to undertake under clause 11 (1) (k)?
—It seems to me a pity that Hansard cannot pick up the cynicism and the tone of voice that Senator Gareth Evans used.
—I was thinking that too. I do not agree with Senator Walters often, but I do agree on this.

—Yes. I feel it is a great shame that Hansard cannot make little notations. It seems to me that what Senator Evans is proposing is that the Commission take the States on. The States, as a rule, have money to fight it in the courts, and no doubt, as Senator Evans indicated, those fights will go on in the courts. Does the same thing apply to the electoral laws of local governments? Will the Commission be looking at the elections of local governments in the same way as they will be looking at the elections of the State governments?

—I suppose technically they could, but I do not think there is any expectation or indication of any desire that they should at this stage. As to Senator Macklin's question, I indicate that it would, I suppose, be technically possible for a similar inquiry to be conducted by the Commission under the powers in clause 11 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill which mirror in some respects the powers in the original Human Rights Commission Act. It would not be in relation to clause 11 (1) (e) that the Commission would be acting because the enactments referred to are not State enactments but Commonwealth and Territory ones. The power the Commission would have to be acting under would be paragraph (j) which gives a power to report to the Minister as to laws that should be made by the Parliament or action taken on matters relating to human rights. It is much less explicit and direct.
—Does this apply under paragraph (k)?

—We can use paragraphs (j) and (k) together in that sense. It is technically possible to do it, but it is a far more direct route to go down the explicit provision in the Bill of Rights Bill itself which specifically refers, among other things, to State enactments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always very cautious when anyone says `practically speaking, yes we could do it, but of course, we never would'. That is not the sort of legislation I think ought be possible to be passed through this Senate. To begin with I do not trust Senator Gareth Evans. I know very well that the Australian Labor Party has on its platform a provision to do away with the Senate. That has been on the Labor Party platform for many years. It was Senator Evans who cynically said at one of the Party meetings that the provision ought to be taken off the platform because it was no longer popular with the people; but that does not mean to say that it can be thrown out. That is the sort of statement that concerns me. Practically speaking, the interference in local council elections can also take place because local councils do not have the sort of money that State governments have, and they would not be able to fight in the courts. The whole thing, obviously, can mean interference with the States' electoral laws. It is the prime intention of the Government that the Commission can also go into local government election laws, and into the Senate itself.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 21 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Qantas appointed Yves Saint Laurent, The French couturier, to design its new uniforms as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 August 1985; if so:
(a) how widely did Qantas advertise for this appointment and what time limit was set for local designers to produce and submit design portfolios.
(b) were any leading Australian designers asked to submit designs, and were local designers given equal opportunity with overseas designers.
(c) what funds have been spent by Qantas in its search and consultation with overseas designers.

(d) has Qantas actually commissioned the new design to be done by Yves Saint Laurent; if so, will Qantas reconsider its decision, and allow for a local, rather than overseas designer, to be appointed.
(2) Does Qantas have any plans for its staff to wear locally designed uniforms during the Bicentennial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Qantas has advised that it has accepted Yves Saint Laurent's design for the Company's new uniforms for flight attendants and key customer contact ground staff.

(a) For some 15 months the Company sought an Australian designed uniform, using an independent panel of distinguished fashion and design experts to evaluate the various submissions. Following expressions of interest by some 43 Australian designers, a short list of eight recognised Australian designers was given two months to prepare a design concept and present this to the judging panel. The panel recommended to Qantas that none of the submissions was acceptable, but if the Company still desired an Australian design, one of the eight finalists could be given a second opportunity to develop a totally new concept. As the Company was most anxious to commission an Australian designer, one of the finalists was given a further six months for this task.

On 13 March 1985 this designer made a final presentation to three Australian members of the judging panel. It was the unanimous conclusion of these judges that this further attempt did not meet the overall standard of design excellence that was needed. This conclusion was supported at the time by the Staff Advisory Panel, which has been actively involved in this project. This panel consists of representatives nominated by the Cabin Crew Associations, Federated Clerks Union and the Australian Transport Officers Association.

Following the disappointing outcome of attempts by Qantas to obtain an Australian designed uniform, the judging panel at the Company's request put forward a list of leading international designers who were then approached. After consideration of the business submissions put forward by those designers, the Company entered into an agreement with Yves Saint Laurent to present a design submission.

(b) Qantas believes it has given Australian designers considerable opportunity to create the new uniforms. Furthermore, the Company believes that it has given local designers preference by initially only seeking Australian design submissions.

(c) As regards the costs associated with search and consultation with overseas designers, one Company representative was sent for discussions with international designers. Qantas has advised that these costs are difficult to quantify, as other matters quite separate from the uniform issue were also covered while overseas. However, expenses incurred on accommodation, meals and other associated travel costs were in accordance with the normal conditions applying to Company personnel travelling on duty.

Subsequently a staff advisory panel, made up of nine staff representatives nominated by their respective unions and two employees representing management travelled to Paris for discussions with Yves Saint Laurent from 3-7 September 1985 on the design of the proposed new uniforms. Also accompanying the panel was Ken Cato, the Melbourne designer who has been working with Yves Saint Laurent. Qantas has advised that the cost of sending the panel to Paris was approximately $15,000, which covered hotel accommodation, meals and other associated expenses in accordance with various industrial awards. Travel to Paris was by way of London, and Qantas has advised that in line with Company policy, no commercial passengers were denied seats on its services to enable the panel members to travel to and from Paris.

(d) Acceptance of the Yves Saint Laurent design was announced by Qantas on 27 November 1985. The company announced that the uniforms will be manufactured entirely in Australia, at a total cost of $2 million, and that Australian fabrics will be used wherever possible. Manufacture will commence shortly, and the new uniforms should begin appearing on Qantas aircraft and in Company offices from the middle of this year.
(2) Qantas has advised that its new uniforms will have a life span of 5 to 7 years, and that the new design will therefore be in place prior to, during and after the Bicentennial Year.
