QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Queensland Government still fail to allocate the necessary funds to enable the Blue Nursing Service to operate at maximum efficiency.

(2) As the Federal Government subsidises Home Nursing organisations on a dollar-for-dollar basis with the States, does this mean that almost $4 million in Federal funds which is available to Queensland is not being taken up.

(3) In view of the invaluable work done by the Blue Nursing Service in giving home nursing to the aged and disabled, is there any action the Federal Government can take to persuade the Queensland Government to increase its allocation to the Blue Nursing Service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In Queensland home nursing is provided by 6 organisations of which the largest is the Blue Nursing Service. This service provides nearly 400 nurses, in addition to those already employed when the Home Nursing Scheme commenced operation in November 1956, to meet domiciliary nursing needs. Each nurse costs the Service in the region of $25,000-$28,000. This cost is not met in total by State/Commonwealth contributions, and the Service must raise its own funds to make up the salary shortfall.

(2) The Blue Nursing Service was estimated in November 1984 to be entitled to receive, on the basis of numbers of nurses employed, almost $4 million in Commonwealth subsidy above the amount expected to be paid to it in 1984-85.

Funding is not quite on a dollar for dollar basis. The Blue Nursing Service was established before 1956 and under present legislative arrangements, is entitled to a Commonwealth subsidy of $18,580 pa for each nurse employed after the commencement of the Scheme in November 1956. However, it can only obtain this amount if the State matches it. In November 1984 it was estimated that in 1984-85 the Service would be employing 418.29 nurses in addition to those already employed when the scheme became effective. This number of nurses, at the rate of $18,580 pa, would entitle the Service to a Commonwealth subsidy of $7,747,860. However, the Queensland Government advised that the State would pay only about 50% of the new rate. State assistance would therefore be $3,850,525, with an additional $60,000 coming from local government authorities. This meant that the Blue Nursing Service was entitled to an additional $3,827,336 from the Commonwealth to which it could not gain access because of State funding limits.

(3) The State Government has primary responsibility for health and welfare services in Queensland. The Commonwealth is presently taking all action possible to achieve improvements in the provision of domiciliary care services. All States and the Commonwealth are agreed that there is an imbalance between institutional and community care services. The introduction of the new Home and Community Care Program will help to develop community services. Four existing legislative programs are incorporated under HACC including the Home Nursing Subsidy Act. All States reached agreement with the Commonwealth to participate in the Program to develop a range of basic maintenance and support services. Existing rates will be paid to organisations, and development may occur through the additional $65 million provided from 1984-85 to 1986-87 pending the development of guidelines on the quality of services, revised funding arrangements etc.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the exchange of notes between the United States (US) and Australian Governments relating to the Haig/Street Agreement (1981), as well as the Agreement itself, provide that the Australian Government is to have consultations with the US and that the Australian Government's agreement to any upgrading of B52 operations relevant to stagings through Australia is required.
(2) Given the upgrading of the Strategic Offensive Forces in Guam over the next 18 months have consultations between the US and Australian Governments occurred.
(3) Has the Government given permission for the continuation of B52 stagings under the 1981 Haig/Street Agreement and the extension of the Agreement in 1982 after the deployments to Guam take place.
(4) Can the Government assure the Australian people that none of the B52 bombers are armed or nuclear-armed through some Australian Government verification procedures.

(5) Will the Government confirm that the US policy of neither confirming or denying whether its craft are nuclear-armed or not, is irrelevant in this case as the B52s staged through Australia are meant to be neither armed nor nuclear-armed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The exchange of notes of 11 March 1981, which constitutes an Agreement between the United States and Australian Governments concerning the staging of USAF B52 aircraft and associated KC 135 tanker aircraft through Australia, provides inter alia that the agreement of the Australian Government will be obtained before the facilities at RAAF Base Darwin are used in support of any category of operations other than ``for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training purposes''. The Agreement also provides that arrangements will be made for consultations to ensure that the Australian Government has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B52 staging operations through Australia and that the Agreement shall continue in force until terminated on one year's notice in writing by either Government.

(2) While there have been routine consultations between Australian and US personnel involved in arrangements for B52 flights in Australia, no formal consultations specifically concerning US plans to strengthen its forces in Guam have taken place between the two Governments. No proposals have been made to alter the nature of B52 operations through Australia.

(4) All the B52 aircraft which have been staged through Australia have conducted low level navigation training flights on the basis of the arrangements announced by the then Minister for Defence on 3 February 1980. This statement, which was agreed by the US, provides that the aircraft ``would be unarmed and carry no bombs''. The Australian Government is confident that all USAF aircraft staged through Australia have in fact been unarmed. This confidence is derived not only from our firm belief in the good faith of our ally, but also from the particular operational characteristics of the agreed B52 activities. For safety reasons, it is not practice to carry weapons of any sort in aircraft undertaking low level navigation flights. Moreover, the stringent security measures which the US Air Force always takes to protect its nuclear weapons while on the ground are not applied when B52s stage through Darwin. In light of this the Australian Government sees no requirement for verification arrangements.

(5) The arrangements which cover B52s staging through Australia do not contravene the US policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons on board its ships and aircraft since the B52s are unarmed and carry no bombs.
